Patient: Hi, I have been vomiting for 1 week and my blood pressure is 143/93 when it usually runs 110/60. I have been short of breath at times and feeling a stinging feeling in my heart. This just came on suddenly. What does all those symptoms mean?

Doctor: Your symptoms suggest that you may be experiencing some form of cardiovascular event or a condition that is affecting your heart and lungs. Vomiting, shortness of breath, and chest pains can be symptoms of heart attack, heart failure, or other heart-related conditions.

It is important to seek immediate medical attention to rule out any life-threatening conditions. Please go to the nearest hospital or emergency room as soon as possible to be evaluated and treated.

Patient: My one year old baby vomits at least once a day. It's been his routine since he was one month old. Sometimes he vomits twice or thrice especially when trying any new food. He also has a phlegm problem. I give him food in puree form and he eats it easily, but right after eating or some time after 2 or 3 hours he vomits. NOW I have shifted to Pakistan from Dubai and this problem has increased because he is not taking even his 3 meals in a day. But with only two meals he vomits at least once in a day. His weight is 12.7 now. Just before one month in UAE his weight was 13.9. I am very tense over this situation.

Doctor: It sounds like your one-year-old baby has been experiencing regular vomiting and a phlegm problem. This can be concerning, as it might indicate a health issue that needs to be addressed promptly. Vomiting can be caused by a variety of reasons, including but not limited to food allergies, infections, or digestive issues.

It's important to bring your baby to a doctor in Pakistan to undergo a thorough examination and diagnostic tests to determine the cause of his vomiting and phlegm problem. The doctor may recommend tests such as a complete blood count (CBC) to check for any abnormalities in the white blood cell count that could indicate an infection, and a stool sample test to rule out any gastrointestinal infections.

In the meantime, it's important to maintain a consistent diet for your baby, avoiding any new foods that could trigger vomiting. Breastfeeding or formula feeding may be preferred for babies with digestive issues to ensure proper nutrition and hydration. Additionally, avoid giving your baby solid foods that are high in fiber or rich in fat, which can burden the digestive system.

If your baby's weight loss continues to be concerning, your doctor may recommend nutritional supplements or formula with higher calories to ensure adequate weight gain.

Please seek immediate medical attention for your baby to rule out any underlying health conditions and ensure proper treatment and management of his symptoms.

Patient: I have had four surgeries on a broken humerus, the head was snapped off the bone. First, a plate was put in to hold together, then removed because a screw broke and caught on plate. It was fused with cadaver bone. Three months later, it broke again from an auto accident. The third surgery put another plate back in and my own bone was used for hip, but prior to surgery a muscle test was done and at the time, I had lost over 30% of my muscle. Infection set in and after a month of iv antibiotics of Vancomiacin, the plate was put back in. This last surgery was done a week ago. There was always hardness, like a rock was in my arm, after the second surgery. I was wondering if it's possible that I have myopathies and if so, how do I know? Four of the five tests for infection were positive prior to the third surgery when the plate was put back in.

Doctor: Thank you for providing your medical history. Based on your description, it seems like you have had a series of complex surgeries related to a broken humerus. The presence of infection and the multiple surgeries can contribute to muscle weakness and other related issues. However, myopathies refer to a group of diseases that affect the muscle, and they can be either inherited or acquired.

To determine if you have a myopathy, several tests can be conducted. First, a physical examination will be performed to assess your muscle strength, tone, and any visible changes in the muscle structure. This may include testing your reflexes and examining specific muscle groups for any abnormalities.

Blood tests can also be ordered to measure the levels of creatine kinase (CK), an enzyme that is released into the bloodstream when muscle damage occurs. Elevated CK levels can indicate muscle damage but not specifically a myopathy.

Electromyography (EMG) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the muscles. It can help identify any underlying muscle disorders by examining the electrical patterns of the muscles.

If there is a suspicion of a genetic basis for a myopathy, genetic testing may be considered. This testing can identify specific gene mutations that are associated with inherited myopathies.

It's important to note that the presence of infection and its treatment can also contribute to muscle issues. The antibiotics you were given for the infection may have had side effects on your muscles, and the infection itself can lead to muscle inflammation and weakness.

Based on your history, it seems like you have already had some tests conducted prior to surgery. It's recommended to review your test results with your surgeon or primary care provider to assess if any further testing is recommended to determine the cause of your muscle issues.

Please follow up with your surgeon or primary care provider for further evaluation and testing to determine the cause of your muscle issues and to ensure proper management of your condition.

Patient: I took Crestor for about 6 months - 10 mg - since going off of it, I have had heart palpitations usually at night. Went to emergency room on Memorial Day weekend - they admitted me for 2 days said it was AD-fib. I think it was the Crestor... I now take Pravastatin but still have the heart skips at night also am taking a beta blocker and blood thinner now because of the skips pooling blood and do not want a stroke from it. What do you think?

Doctor: It is possible that the Crestor could have contributed to your heart palpitations and other symptoms. Crestor is a statin medication that is used to lower cholesterol levels, but it can sometimes cause side effects such as heart palpitations, arrhythmias, and other cardiac issues.

However, it is also important to consider other potential causes for your symptoms. AD-fib (atrial fibrillation) is a common condition that can cause heart palpitations and other cardiac symptoms. It is possible that you may have developed AD-fib while taking Crestor, but it could also be a separate issue.

Based on your current medication regimen, you are already being treated for AD-fib and other cardiac conditions. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it is important to consult with your cardiologist for further evaluation and treatment recommendations. They can perform additional tests and assess your condition to determine the best course of action.

Patient: I have spinning sensations when I go to sleep and get up in the morning. In fact, the spinning sensations affected me while I was sleeping. I also observed vomitting sensations immediately after such spinning sensations. I would like to know about this problem and its cure.

Doctor: Your symptoms suggest a vestibular disturbance, which is a problem with the balance system in your inner ear. This can cause spinning sensations, dizziness, and nausea.

Cure: The first step in treating vestibular disturbance is to rest and avoid any activities that might make your symptoms worse. If the symptoms persist, you may need to see a doctor for a more thorough evaluation. The doctor may recommend vestibular exercises to help your brain better process the signals from your balance system. If the symptoms are severe or persistent, your doctor may prescribe medication to help control the symptoms.

If your symptoms are caused by a more serious condition, such as a brain tumor or inner ear infection, your doctor may recommend further testing and treatment.

Please note that this is not a professional medical advice and you should consult your own doctor for a comprehensive evaluation and treatment advice.

Patient: "For the past 2 weeks, I've had pain in my shoulder that's been tight. My doctor did an X-ray and gave me a cortizone shot. He mentioned a small tear. The next day, I went to see the joint specialist who gave me 2 more shots. He said I have bone spurs but needed to get the pain and swelling down from bursitis. 4 days later, I can move my arm very little but more than the last 2 weeks. My question is how long does bursitis last? He mentioned in the back of his mind he hopes it's not (a very long name) of something that brings a very painful nerve disease. Thanks for your help."

Doctor's Response: Bursitis can last for a variable amount of time depending on the severity of the condition and how quickly it is treated. In general, bursitis can last anywhere from a few weeks to several months. However, if the condition is left untreated or not properly managed, it can last longer and even become chronic.

The good news is that with appropriate treatment, most cases of bursitis can resolve relatively quickly. The treatment typically involves rest, ice, compression, and elevation of the affected area, as well as NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) or other pain relievers as needed.

If your doctor suspects that you may have a more serious condition such as a very painful nerve disease, he may recommend further testing or referral to a specialist for further evaluation. It's important to follow your doctor's advice and take the necessary steps to manage your condition effectively.

Based on the information you have provided, here is a possible diagnosis:

Your Bradycardia may have been caused by the Tachycardia ablation procedure performed in 2004. Bradycardia is a condition where the heart rate is abnormally slow, usually fewer than 60 beats per minute. Your normal heart rate of 39 to 45 beats per minute falls within the Bradycardia range.

Your blood pressure is slightly high, which might be due to the Bradycardia. High blood pressure can cause strain on the heart, leading to Bradycardia.

During exercise, you feel short of breath until properly warmed up, which might be due to the low heart rate. However, your recovery time is just a few minutes or less, which indicates that your heart rate might not be too low.

At rest, you often get chest pains, which might be caused by Bradycardia. Chest pains can be a common symptom of Bradycardia.

You also take Ranitidine for Acid reflux, which is a common medication for acid reflux disease. This medication does not seem to be related to your Bradycardia.

You have also noticed that you keep having reoccurring slight head aches when resting. This might be a side effect of the Ranitidine medication or it might be caused by the Bradycardia.

Your worry that your Bradycardia is getting worse as your heart rate is slowing down might be valid. However, it is important to note that a slow heart rate does not always indicate worsening Bradycardia. It might be a normal physiological response in some individuals.

To further evaluate your condition, it is recommended to consult a cardiologist for a detailed evaluation and treatment options. The cardiologist will likely perform a physical examination, order some tests such as an ECG (electrocardiogram) to assess the heart's electrical activity, and recommend appropriate treatment based on the findings.

Patient: Hi, I have these small rashes on my shoulders, upper arms, and breast. They have been there for a couple weeks now and they are very itchy. They are nickel size or smaller, some of them look dark red kind of like a scar. What could it be? At first I thought it was ringworm but I have had ringworm before and it looks nothing like that.

Doctor: Based on your description, it seems like you might have eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis. Eczema is a common skin condition that causes red, itchy patches on the skin. It often appears in the same areas as you described, such as the shoulders, upper arms, and breast. The appearance of the rash can vary, and some patches may look similar to scars due to the healing process.

Patient: Is it contagious?

Doctor: Eczema is not contagious. It is a non-infectious condition caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. It is not spreadable to others.

Patient: How can I get rid of it?

Doctor: There are several options to treat eczema. First, it is important to maintain a daily skin care routine, especially with a soap-free cleanser and a thick moisturizer to help relieve the itching and keep the skin hydrated. Avoiding triggers like harsh soaps, perfumes, and certain fabrics can also help reduce flare-ups. If the rash is severe or persistent, topical steroids or immune-modulating agents may be prescribed by a dermatologist. In some cases, oral medication may be necessary for severe cases.

Patient: Is there any way to prevent it from happening again?

Doctor: While there is no guaranteed way to prevent eczema from happening again, there are certain measures you can take to reduce the risk of flare-ups. Regularly moisturizing the skin, avoiding triggers like harsh soaps and perfumes, and using appropriate clothing materials can help maintain skin health and prevent eczema from recurring. If you have a family history of eczema, genetics may play a role in your risk of developing the condition again.

Patient: I have been suffering from Restless Leg Syndrome for many years, and it has become unbearable in the last 10 months. I am taking Ropinirole, which is the generic equivalent of Requip. I also take iron, Vitamin C, B, D, and magnesium supplements, but nothing is working. My legs spasm and twitch, especially in the afternoon and evening, and I cannot relax. Is there anything else I can do? Should I see a neurologist? I appreciate any assistance you can provide.

Doctor: I am sorry to hear that your Restless Leg Syndrome has been causing you so much discomfort. Restless Leg Syndrome can be a challenging condition to manage, and it can be frustrating when traditional treatments fail to provide relief.

Firstly, it is important to ensure that your current treatment is working for you. If you are not experiencing any improvement with Ropinirole, it may be necessary to explore other options. Your doctor may consider increasing the dosage or switching to a different medication that is more effective for your specific symptoms.

In addition to medication, there are non-medication strategies that may help you manage your Restless Leg Syndrome. These include:

1. Relaxation techniques: Try practices like deep breathing, mindfulness, or progressive muscle relaxation to help you relax and reduce the spasms and twitching.
2. Exercise: Regular exercise can help improve circulation and reduce symptoms. Consider activities like walking, cycling, or swimming.
3. Sleep hygiene: Establishing healthy sleep habits can help reduce symptoms during the day. This includes going to bed at a consistent time, avoiding stimulating activities before bed, and creating a relaxing bedtime routine.
4. Dietary changes: Some people find that avoiding caffeine and alcohol can reduce symptoms. Additionally, increasing the intake of iron-rich foods like red meat, beans, or leafy greens may help support your iron levels.

If your symptoms continue to persist despite these measures, it may be beneficial to consult a neurologist. A neurologist has expertise in diagnosing and managing neurological conditions like Restless Leg Syndrome. They can review your symptoms and treatment history and make recommendations for further testing or alternative treatment options if necessary.

Remember that every case of Restless Leg Syndrome is unique, and there are individualized treatment options available. It is important to work closely with your healthcare provider to develop a management plan that works for you.

Patient: I have dark spots and bumps around my bikini area due to shaving. I have two bumps that have grown over the years and I can't get rid of them, so embarrassing. I've tried using Proactive, but it's not working. I've also tried the lemon home remedy, but I'm getting impatient. Dermatologists are very expensive. Is there any other quick and easy way to solve this problem? I'll try waxing once everything goes away.

Doctor: There are several options available for treating dark spots and bumps around the bikini area. One quick and easy method is the use of over-the-counter products containing hydroquinone, a topical whitening agent. It can be found in creams, lotions, or gels, and it works by lightening the skin color.

Another option is the use of retinoids, which are derivatives of vitamin A that help to exfoliate the skin and reduce the appearance of bumps. You can use retinoid creams or gels at night after cleansing and moisturizing.

If you prefer a more natural approach, you can try using lemon juice or other citrus juices topically. Lemon juice contains citric acid, which can help lighten the skin. However, it can also cause skin irritation, so it's important to use it sparingly and only on areas that are not sensitive.

If you have dark spots and bumps that have been persistent for years, it's important to see a dermatologist for a professional evaluation. Dermatologists have the expertise to determine the cause of your skin condition and recommend the most effective treatment options. The treatment plan may involve creams, laser therapy, or other advanced techniques depending on your specific condition.

Waxing is another option, but it may not be suitable for everyone. Waxing can remove hair and some of the bumps, but it may not be effective for eliminating dark spots. It's important to find a reputable salon or esthetician who is experienced in waxing techniques for sensitive areas.

In conclusion, there are several options available for treating dark spots and bumps around the bikini area. You can try over-the-counter products containing hydroquinone, retinoids, or lemon juice. However, if your condition persists or if you have concerns about your skin health, it's important to consult a dermatologist for a professional evaluation and recommendation.

Patient's husband underwent a laparoscopic-assisted cardiomyotomy one month ago. He was diagnosed with achalasia cardia through a barium swallow test and endoscopy. Before the surgery, he had difficulty swallowing solid food and needed to drink lots of water for food to pass into his stomach. Now, after the surgery, he used to vomit digested food once a day and sometimes feels like there is something stuck at the operative site.

Based on the information provided, it seems like your husband's condition after the surgery is normal and expected. achalasia cardia is a condition where the lower esophageal sphincter doesn't relax properly, causing food to become stuck in the esophagus. The laparoscopic-assisted cardiomyotomy surgery is designed to relax this sphincter and improve swallowing.

However, it can take some time for the surgery to take effect and for your husband to fully recover. He may experience some discomfort and sensations in his chest and throat for a while after the surgery. If he experiences any unexpected symptoms or concerns, it's important to contact his doctor immediately.

In the meantime, here are some tips to help your husband manage his condition:

1. Eat small meals and avoid eating too fast.
2. Drink plenty of fluids, especially water, to help with swallowing.
3. Avoid lying down after meals to prevent food from getting stuck in the esophagus.
4. If he experiences any pain or discomfort, take over-the-counter pain relievers as needed.
5. Contact his doctor if he experiences any unexpected symptoms or concerns.

Please note that these are general tips and it's important to follow the advice of your husband's doctor. They will be able to provide more specific guidance on his recovery and management of achalasia cardia.

Remember, every case is unique, and the best course of treatment may vary depending on the individual's condition and response to medication.

Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on the information you have provided, your son has been suffering from fever since yesterday and has been given crocin (paracetamol) syrup every 6 hours. However, the fever is returning every 6 hours. This morning, he complained of stomach pain.

If your son's doctor determines that his symptoms are caused by a viral infection, the doctor may recommend giving him antiviral medication. If the cause of the symptoms is bacterial, the doctor may prescribe antibiotics.

In the meantime, you can continue giving your son crocin (paracetamol) syrup to help reduce his fever. Please note that giving medication every 6 hours is sufficient. However, do not exceed the recommended dose as it may cause side effects.

It is also important to ensure that your son drinks plenty of fluids, rests, and avoids exposure to smoke and other irritants that may worsen his condition.

If your son's symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention promptly.

He had one on his tummy which I popped after a bath and it left a mark but it is gone. They are red with white head and looks like a dimple in the middle and are hard. I need them gone. What should I do? I read online that it might be a staph infection. I need help.

Doctor: Thank you for bringing your son's medical concern to my attention. Based on your description, it does sound like your son may have staph infection, which is a common skin infection caused by Staphylococcus bacteria.

To treat the infection, I recommend the following steps:

1. Keep the bumps clean and dry to prevent further infection.
2. Apply a topical antibiotic cream, such as mupirocin or bacitracin, to the infected areas. This will help to kill the bacteria and reduce the inflammation.
3. If the infection does not improve within a few days, or if the bumps are spreading or becoming more painful, please seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor may recommend oral antibiotics or other treatment options if necessary.

It is important to note that staph infections can be contagious, so please wash your hands frequently and avoid sharing personal items like towels and clothing with your son until the infection is fully resolved.

If you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to contact me. I hope your son's condition improves soon!

In a normal heart, the left ventricle is a muscular chamber responsible for pumping oxygenated blood to the body. The shape and function of the left ventricle can be affected by various conditions, such as heart disease or high blood pressure.

The term "mild unfolding of the aorta" refers to a slightly dilated aorta, which is the largest artery in the body responsible for delivering oxygenated blood to the body. Aortic dilation can be caused by various conditions, such as aging, high blood pressure, or genetic predisposition.

The chest X-ray picked up these findings, which might be related to your scoliosis. However, it's important to note that these findings alone do not necessarily indicate any significant health issues. Patient: I have just been fitted with an air cast boot because I broke two bones in my right foot near my little toe due to falling down stairs. I am worried about the size of the boot I am wearing because I provided the wrong shoe size (UK 6 but the boot is size 6 Canadian size, as it was fitted in a hospital in Canada). Will this delay or do more harm to the bones healing correctly? I would appreciate your advice so that I have time to go back to the hospital if necessary.

Doctor's Advice:

The size of the air cast boot does not significantly affect the healing of the broken bones. The boot is designed to provide support and stability to the injured area, which is more important for the bones to heal correctly. If the boot fits comfortably and does not pinch or compress the injured area, it should be adequate for supporting the foot while the bones heal.

If the boot is too large or too small, it can be uncomfortable and may cause additional strain on the injured area, which could potentially delay healing. However, if the boot is just a slightly larger size, it should not cause any significant harm to the bones' healing process.

If you are concerned about the size of the boot, it is recommended to return to the hospital for a follow-up appointment so that your doctor can check the injured area and ensure that it is being properly supported. Your doctor can also provide advice on whether you should continue wearing the air cast boot or if a different type of footwear would be more appropriate for your injury.

As for the pregnancy test, it is recommended that you undergo a blood test 10-14 days after the transfer to determine whether the pregnancy is successful. If the pregnancy is successful, the hormone level will continue to rise, and the doctor can further confirm the pregnancy through ultrasound examination.

The symptoms of pregnancy may vary from person to person. Common symptoms include:

1. Irregular menstruation: If you are pregnant, menstruation will stop.

2. Fatigue: After pregnancy, the body's hormone level changes, leading to fatigue and lack of energy.

3. Nausea and vomiting: Some women may experience nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, which is also known as morning sickness.

4. Frequent urination: Pregnancy will increase the frequency of urination.

5. Breast tenderness: Pregnancy will cause breast tenderness and breast enlargement.

If you experience any of the above symptoms, it is recommended that you consult your doctor for a pregnancy test and examination.

I have also had throat soreness along with neck, and jaw pain.

Doctor: It is difficult to determine the exact cause of the rash without conducting a physical examination, but based on your symptoms and description, it could be a number of different conditions. One possibility is a fungal infection, such as candidiasis or tinea. These infections often cause rashes in the genital area and may be accompanied by itching and soreness. Another possibility is a skin condition such as eczema or psoriasis.

If you have any concerns or if the symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment, it is important to seek medical attention promptly. Patient: It is the 4th day of my embryo transfer. I am experiencing pain on the side near my waist (left side) while sleeping and changing positions. I also have a rapid heart rate, fatigue, and a little shortness of breath. I am developing gas in my stomach and feel better when the gas is released. Is this normal?

Doctor: Thank you for your detailed description. During the early stages of pregnancy, some women may experience discomfort and symptoms similar to what you are describing. However, it is important to be cautious and not self-diagnose.

Firstly, the rapid heart rate and shortness of breath could be symptoms of early pregnancy, as your body adjusts to the changes. Fatigue is also a common complaint, as your body is working hard to support the pregnancy.

Secondly, regarding the pain on the side near your waist, it could be due to implantation or other early pregnancy-related issues. However, it is important to rule out any potential causes of concern, such as an ectopic pregnancy or other conditions that may require medical attention.

Finally, the development of gas in your stomach could be due to changes in your digestive system during pregnancy. However, if the gas is persistent or causing discomfort, it is recommended to consult your doctor for further evaluation.

In summary, while some of your symptoms may be normal during early pregnancy, it is important to consult your doctor for a professional evaluation. They will be able to assess your condition and provide guidance on any necessary steps to take moving forward. Please take care and do not hesitate to contact your doctor if your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns.

164:
As a pregnant woman, your body is going through many changes, including physiological and anatomical changes that can affect your cardiovascular, respiratory, and nervous systems. The symptoms you are experiencing, such as swollen feet, discoloration, and pain when pressing on the skin, are common in pregnancy and are often due to increased blood volume, pooling of fluid in the ankles and feet, and changes in the circulatory system.

If your symptoms are mild and intermittent, you can consider making lifestyle changes that may help reduce the symptoms. This includes elevating your feet and legs when possible, avoiding sitting or standing for long periods of time, and gradually increasing your physical activity level. You can also consider wearing compression stockings to help reduce fluid pooling in the ankles and feet.

If your symptoms are severe or persistent, it is important to seek medical attention promptly. Your healthcare provider can perform a comprehensive evaluation and recommend appropriate treatment options based on your specific symptoms and health status. They may recommend lifestyle changes, such as those mentioned above, or may prescribe medication or other interventions if necessary.

In addition, it is important to maintain a healthy diet during pregnancy, avoiding salt-rich food items. A balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains can help maintain good health during pregnancy.

If you have any concerns or if your symptoms are severe or persistent, please seek medical attention promptly.

Patient: I fell flat on my face and had a pretty bad fall where I knocked out my front 4 teeth. One is completely gone, one is half-way diagonally chipped, and the other two are chipped at the gum so it looks like they are not there. I understand implants are necessary but that is a long process in which I need to wait. Is there anything that can be done within a week so I don't have to go to school for too long without teeth? I can't put the originals back in because the ER surgeon said they were too shattered.

Doctor: It is important to address this dental situation promptly. Immediately after a traumatic injury like this, it is essential to see a dentist for a thorough examination and evaluation. If the teeth cannot be saved, the next step would be to consider dental implants or bridges as permanent solutions. However, as you mentioned, this process takes time.

In the meantime, temporary solutions can be considered. One option is to use crowns or caps to cover the exposed tooth roots or remaining tooth fragments. This can provide immediate cosmetic improvement and protect the sensitive pulp tissue inside the tooth socket.

Another option is to use a removable partial denture or bridge. This device can be custom-made to match your other teeth and provide a functional and cosmetic replacement for the missing teeth.

It is important to maintain good oral hygiene and avoid any pressure or trauma on the injured area while these temporary solutions are being considered and prepared. I recommend you seek prompt dental attention to discuss these options further and determine the best course of action for your situation.

172: Patient: Hi. I have had pain in the front of my neck for 3 weeks. I have sudden fevers and sweating at night, as well as an increased heart rate. A thyroid scan showed infection of the thyroid. My hemoglobin has also decreased and I have lost weight in the past month. I am a 58 year old male.
173:
Patient: I have been a heavy drinker all my life. Drinking 12-16 units per day when I was younger, now I still drink the same amount but I take 2 days off per week. I check my levels 2-3 times per year and my ALT and AST have been normal for the last 5 years, but now they have spiked to 70 and 120, and this was after not drinking any alcohol for 2 weeks. I noticed that after stopping alcohol in anticipation of my test that my liver felt swollen and continues to feel that way. I am sure alcohol is / has contributed to the problem but want to know if there is any other condition that I should be worried about. I already plan to cut way back on alcohol consumption.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your information with me. Based on your description, your heavy alcohol consumption has likely taken a toll on your liver. It is important to recognize that alcohol can be a toxin to the liver and long-term heavy drinking can lead to a condition called cirrhosis, which is a scarring of the liver. This can result in a range of health issues and it may be one of the reasons your ALT and AST levels have spiked. 

To address your current health concerns, I recommend that we arrange for a full liver panel blood test to get a better understanding of your current liver function. Additionally, an ultrasound or CT scan of your liver would be helpful to visualize any potential damage or scarring. Please also be aware that there could be other conditions that may be causing your symptoms, such as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or autoimmune hepatitis. These conditions would require different treatment strategies than simply cutting back on alcohol.  

With regards to your alcohol consumption, I recommend that you stop drinking alcohol entirely while we assess your liver health. If your ALT and AST levels normalize after stopping alcohol, then it is likely that alcohol is a contributing factor to your liver issues. If you experience withdrawal symptoms such as tremors, hallucinations, or seizures when stopping alcohol, it would be important to let me know so that we can manage those symptoms accordingly. 

Lastly, it is essential that you follow up with a hepatologist (a doctor specializing in liver diseases) for further evaluation and potential treatment recommendations. I will schedule an appointment for you with our hepatologist and we will go from there. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns.
174: As a doctor, I recommend that you go to the nearest hospital or clinic for a thorough examination and treatment. The doctor can examine the wound and determine the appropriate treatment plan. It is important to avoid self-diagnosis and self-medication, as this can lead to worsening of the condition or even risk of infection. I hope you get well soon.

177:
Patient: I have a round, well-defined anechoic cystic structure in both the right and left lobes of the liver. I also have multiple kidney stones in the right kidney, which is smaller than the left one, and prominent extrarenal pelvises bilaterally. The common bile duct and main pancreatic duct are dilated to the upper limits of normal, and the gallbladder is prominent. What does this mean? I am in pain!

Doctor: Based on your description, it appears that you have several medical conditions that require further evaluation and treatment. Let's break down what each finding could mean and what the next steps might be.

1. Cystic structures in the liver: These could be benign or malignant, but without further imaging and/or biopsy, it's difficult to determine their exact nature. It's recommended to follow up with a liver ultrasound or CT scan to better characterize the cysts and potentially rule out any underlying malignancy.

2. Multiple kidney stones: These are mineral deposits that can cause pain and obstruct the flow of urine. Depending on the size and location of the stones, treatment options may include conservative management with pain medication, lithotripsy (breaks the stones into smaller pieces), or surgical removal.

3. Smaller right kidney and prominent extrarenal pelvises: These findings suggest possible structural abnormalities or hydronephrosis (fluid buildup in the kidney). It's important to evaluate the kidney function and urine flow to determine if there are any obstructions that may be causing the symptoms.

4. Dilation of the common bile duct and main pancreatic duct: This could indicate a potential blockage or narrowing in these ducts, which could lead to gallstones or pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas). It's recommended to monitor these findings with repeat imaging and consider endoscopic procedures if symptoms persist or worsen.

5. Gallbladder prominence: This could be a normal variant or due to gallstones or gallbladder wall thickening, which can indicate gallbladder disease or infection. It's important to assess for any associated symptoms such as abdominal pain or jaundice (yellowing of the skin) that might require further evaluation.

In summary, based on your findings, it appears that you have several medical conditions that require further evaluation and treatment. It's important to consult with a hepatologist (liver specialist), nephrologist (kidney specialist), and gastroenterologist (digestive system specialist) to develop a comprehensive treatment plan that addresses all of your symptoms and medical conditions. Additionally, it's essential to manage your pain appropriately to ensure your comfort while undergoing these evaluations and potential treatments.

The pain is constant. What is your recommended medication for pain relief? I have been trying to do stretches, but there is still pain in my leg and my knee is very tender. I must be bent over to walk with even the cane. Is there a good Neurologist in the Fort Lauderdale, Fl. area that you could suggest? By the way, I am age 75. Jim T.

Doctor: I am sorry to hear about your condition, Jim. Neuropathy can be a challenging condition to manage, especially after a fall. Firstly, it is important to ensure that your back pain and balance issues are properly evaluated and diagnosed by a Neurologist.

Fort Lauderdale, Florida is a large area, so it's likely there are several Neurologists in the area who specialize in balance and vestibular disorders. They can help you find the right Neurologist for your condition.

In addition to seeking medical attention, it's important to continue with physical therapy and exercises that focus on balance and core strengthening. Consider aquatic therapy or pool-based exercises as they can provide low-impact support and improve balance.

184:
Hello, I am a doctor. Your 3-year-old son has jaundice. Jaundice is a condition where the skin and whites of the eyes look yellow due to high levels of bilirubin in the blood. It can be caused by various reasons such as Gilbert's syndrome, hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells), hepatitis, and biliary atresia (blockage of bile ducts).

Based on your description, your son has severe jaundice as his Bilirubin level is very high (357 points). I recommend immediate hospitalization for him. He needs to be evaluated by a pediatrician or a hepatologist (specialist in liver diseases) to determine the cause of jaundice and to start appropriate treatment.

Precautionary measures:

1. Ensure that your son drinks plenty of fluids.
2. Avoid giving him any medication that can damage the liver such as acetaminophen or aspirin.
3. Seek medical attention immediately if his condition worsens or if he has any new symptoms.

Diet: During the period of jaundice, it is recommended to give your son a bland diet that is easy to digest. He can have small meals frequently, avoiding greasy and fried food. Fruits and vegetables are fine, but avoid giving him yellow or orange-colored fruits as they can add to the bilirubin level. Milk and other dairy products are also fine, but limit them to small quantities.

I hope your son gets well soon. It is important to seek medical attention promptly for any health concerns in children.

It is important to see a doctor as soon as possible to determine the cause of your pain and receive appropriate treatment.

Common causes of chest pain can include:

1. Muscle strain or ligament injury
2. Costochondritis (inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone)
3. Pleurisy (inflammation of the pleura, the membranes that cover the lungs)
4. Pericarditis (inflammation of the pericardium, the sac that surrounds the heart)
5. Myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle)
6. Aortic dissection (a tear in the wall of the aorta, the largest blood vessel in the body)
7. Pneumonia or pleural effusion (fluid in the pleural sac)
8. Fractured rib
9. Congenital heart disease
10. Esophageal spasm or reflux

If your pain is severe or persistent, it is important to seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor can perform a physical examination, order tests such as X-rays or blood tests, and recommend appropriate treatment if necessary.

Please do not ignore your symptoms. It is better to be safe than sorry. I hope you get well soon.

She has extensive bruising, affecting her jawline, the area around her eye, and the mid-cheek towards her sternum. There are also three fingerprint-sized bruises on her upper neck where the surgeon held her jaw open. Inside her mouth, there are running sutures from the gum to her cheek, located three teeth in front of the wisdom tooth removal site. As the swelling has started to decrease, a hard lump has formed, not near the tooth removal site but at the site where the gum was sutured to the cheek. She has been taking antibiotics since the surgery.

**Possible Causes for Extra Stitches**

The extra stitches may have been placed to repair any tears or lacerations that may have occurred during the surgery or due to the pressure of the oral surgeon holding her jaw open. This is a common procedure during wisdom tooth removals, especially when there is significant swelling or other issues with the oral cavity. The sutures help promote proper healing and prevent infection.

**Normality of ExtremeBruising**

Bruising after wisdom tooth removal is common, but the extent of bruising can vary from person to person. The location and size of the bruises may be influenced by the amount of trauma during surgery, the position of the teeth, and the patient's overall health. The fact that your daughter is not on any daily medications and does not normally bruise easily suggests that the bruising might be more significant in this case. It's important to note that severe bruising can be a sign of other potential issues, such as clotting disorders or other underlying conditions.

**Recommendations**

It's crucial to monitor your daughter's condition closely. Ensure she continues taking the antibiotics as prescribed to prevent infection. If the hard lump or bruising does not improve within a reasonable time frame or if there are any concerns, consult her dentist or oral surgeon for a follow-up appointment. They can assess her condition and provide further guidance on what to expect after wisdom tooth removal and how to manage the current symptoms.
210:
As a doctor, I cannot provide a final recommendation based on the information provided. However, based on the available information, I can suggest some general guidelines.

However, if your symptoms worsen or if your temperature rises above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, it is recommended to consult your dentist as soon as possible.

In summary, it is recommended to continue with the root canal treatment and monitor your symptoms. If your symptoms worsen or if your temperature rises above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, consult your dentist as soon as possible.
211:

This causes incredible pain and the weakness in my hand can barely hold onto a pencil for a few seconds without dropping. The areas affected are the palm, back of my hand, and where the pulse is (inner wrist). My family and I have Googled the symptoms but can't seem to find a final diagnosis of what is going on with my hand. Thank you.

Doctor: It sounds like you're experiencing some serious hand pain and weakness. This could be caused by a number of different conditions, including carpal tunnel syndrome, tendonitis, or a pinched nerve. Doctor: Based on your symptoms and heart rate variations, it seems like you might be experiencing arrhythmias. Arrhythmias are changes in the heart rate that can cause chest pains and other symptoms. We need to conduct some more tests to confirm the diagnosis and rule out any other possible conditions. In the meantime, it's important to manage your symptoms by avoiding any activities that may increase your heart rate, such as exercise or excitement. Can you do that?
216:
Based on your symptoms, it seems like you may have several issues going on. Firstly, the constipation, abdominal pain, and gas may indicate a gastrointestinal issue such as irritable bowel syndrome or Crohn's disease. The dark yellow urine and dehydration could suggest a problem with your liver or kidneys, which are responsible for filtering and excreting waste from your body. Lastly, the weight loss, weakness, and chest pain could be due to stress or a more serious condition like heartburn or esophageal reflux.

It's important to get a thorough check-up from a gastroenterologist and a general physician to rule out any serious conditions. In the meantime, here are some lifestyle changes that may help:

1. Drink plenty of water - Dehydration can cause your symptoms to worsen.

4. Exercise regularly - This can help improve your overall health and digestive system function.

217:
Patient: A week ago, my 16-year-old daughter fell backwards and hit hard at the back of her head. I took her to the emergency room, and they just did an assessment without doing any X-ray or scanning because she looked fine. Last night, she had a very high fever and a severe throbbing headache. I gave her ibuprofen. This morning, her fever subsided though she is still weak. What should I do?

Doctor: It sounds like your daughter may have had a concussion from the fall. A concussion is a type of brain injury that can cause symptoms like headache, dizziness, confusion, and sometimes fever. The good news is that most concussions heal quickly with rest and simple treatment. Here are some things you can do:

1. Rest: Your daughter needs to rest to give her brain time to heal. Avoid any physical or mental activities that could strain her brain, such as studying, using electronic devices, or playing sports.

2. Monitor Symptoms: Watch for any changes in your daughter's symptoms. If her headache gets worse, if she has any confusion or dizziness, or if her symptoms last longer than a few days, it's important to seek medical attention again.

3. Hydration: Make sure your daughter is drinking plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.

4. Medication: If your daughter's symptoms are severe, your doctor may prescribe medication to help with the pain and inflammation.

5. Follow Up: Schedule a follow-up appointment with your daughter's doctor to ensure she's making a healthy recovery.

Please note that this advice is general and may not apply to all cases. It's important to seek medical attention promptly if your daughter's symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns about her health.
218:
On behalf of your 56-year-old brother who has been experiencing extensive swelling on the bridge of his nose, I understand that this has been a very painful condition for the past two years since he underwent a tooth implant. He has also had Lazer surgery on his eyes due to being unable to bear the pressure on his nose. He experiences stress at work and has had surgery by a plastic surgeon one year ago, but the wound is still weeping. He has taken an intensive course of antibiotics for four weeks and must continue for another two weeks. He has seen an endocrinologist who took blood tests, which they said were normal levels. An MRI scan showed nothing according to a neurologist. The pain is very severe. Could you suggest any other path to go? The implant tooth broke and has been removed, but there is still some titanium in his gum. Could this all be related? He cannot find any help.

Based on the information provided, here are some possible paths to consider:

1. Referral to a Rheumatologist: Since the symptoms have been ongoing for two years and there is a history of Lazer surgery on the eyes, it may be worthwhile to consider referral to a rheumatologist. They specialize in conditions that cause swelling and pain and may have a different perspective on the cause of the symptoms.
2. Evaluation by an Otolaryngologist: An otolaryngologist is a specialist in the evaluation and treatment of conditions related to the ear, nose, and throat. They may have additional insights into the cause of the swelling and pain on the bridge of the nose.
3. Consideration of Alternative Therapies: If the conventional medical approach has not provided relief, it may be worthwhile to explore alternative therapies such as acupuncture, chiropractic, or naturopathy. These therapies may help relieve the pain and swelling while providing overall wellness.
4. Exploration of Allergies or Intolerances: Since the symptoms started after the tooth implant, it may be worthwhile to explore allergies or intolerances to the materials used in the implant or the antibiotics taken. A thorough evaluation by an allergist or immunologist may help identify any potential allergies or intolerances that could be contributing to the symptoms.
5. Evaluation by a Plastic Surgeon: Since the patient has had surgery by a plastic surgeon, it may be beneficial to have a follow-up evaluation to ensure that there are no further issues related to the surgery site or surrounding tissue. The plastic surgeon can provide further guidance on potential causes and treatment options.

It is important to note that each patient's case is unique, and it may take time to determine the underlying cause of the symptoms. It is essential to seek a thorough evaluation by a healthcare professional who specializes in the area of concern. Additionally, it is important to manage stress levels as they can contribute to symptoms and overall well-being. Consider seeking support from a therapist or counselor who can assist with stress management techniques and relaxation methods.
219:

I remain in tension 24 hours worrying about how to get rid of it. I also developed a mania disease in 2003. Now, I also used to take medicine. Please help me because I want to suicide due to not reading and an ill living style for 11 years. Mukesh Patna, 28 years old.

I understand the shame, depression, and moral concerns that you feel after masturbating, which is a normal reaction for many people with these conditions. They may recommend behavioral therapy, which can help you manage your addiction and reduce the frequency of masturbation.

Secondly, it is important to take your medication regularly as prescribed by your doctor. Medication can help manage the symptoms of your mania disease and keep you stable. If you feel that your medication is not working or causing side effects, discuss this with your doctor promptly.

Lastly, consider joining a support group or meeting with other people who are dealing with similar issues. This can provide a safe space to share experiences, coping strategies, and emotional support.

Remember, Mukesh, that you are not alone in this battle. With professional help and support, you can overcome these challenges and live a fulfilling life. Please seek help as soon as possible.
221: Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on your description, if you usually take the pill at the same time every night and have sex without using other contraceptive methods, then you may be protected from pregnancy. However, if you forget to take your pill for a short period of time, there is a risk of pregnancy. The longer the pill is missed, the greater the risk of pregnancy. If you have sex without using contraceptive methods and have sex for more than 12 hours after missing the pill, it is recommended to take emergency contraceptives as soon as possible to reduce the risk of pregnancy. If you have sex for less than 12 hours after missing the pill, you can consider taking the pill as soon as possible to reduce the risk of pregnancy. If you have sex for more than 3 days after missing the pill, it is recommended to take a pregnancy test to determine whether you are pregnant. If you have sex for less than 3 days after missing the pill, it is recommended to take a pregnancy test in time to determine whether you are pregnant. If you have sex for less than 3 days after missing the pill and test positive for pregnancy, it is recommended to seek medical advice promptly.
222:
As a doctor, I would recommend that you see the neurosurgeon as soon as possible. It is important to understand your options and to have a professional evaluate your condition. If you are experiencing chronic back pain, it is important to consider all possible treatment options. 230:
Patient: I am a 40 year old female currently taking warfarin for recent multiple PEs... more recently I have found little bright red spots appearing on several places of my body. I was told they were Cherry angiomas by my chiropractor and that they are caused from too much estrogen... Is that possible? What can I do to treat them? Will they go away? What harm will too much estrogen cause?

Doctor: It is possible that the appearance of Cherry angiomas could be related to high levels of estrogen. Estrogen is a hormone that plays a role in many physiological processes, including the development and regulation of the skin and its pigments. However, the appearance of Cherry angiomas is not always caused by high estrogen levels.

Treatment options for Cherry angiomas include:

1. Observation: If the angiomas are small and asymptomatic, observation may be the best course of action.

2. Topical treatments: Topical creams or gels may be used to reduce the appearance of the angiomas.

3. Surgical removal: If the angiomas are large or causing discomfort, surgical removal may be considered.

It is important to note that while Cherry angiomas may be caused by high estrogen levels, high estrogen levels do not always cause Cherry angiomas. If you have concerns about your estrogen levels, it is recommended that you consult a medical professional for a comprehensive evaluation and testing.

In general, high estrogen levels can have various effects on the body, including but not limited to:

1. Endocrine system: High estrogen levels can affect the function of the endocrine system, leading to changes in hormone production and regulation.

2. Reproductive system: High estrogen levels can affect the reproductive system, leading to changes in menstruation, ovulation, and fertility.

3. Cardiovascular system: High estrogen levels can have positive effects on the cardiovascular system, such as reducing cholesterol levels and blood pressure. However, high levels of estrogen may also increase the risk of blood clots and stroke.

4. Musculoskeletal system: High estrogen levels can affect bone density and muscle strength, leading to changes in bone health and joint function.

5. Central nervous system: High estrogen levels can affect mood, memory, and cognitive function, leading to changes in behavior and thinking patterns.

It is important to note that these effects are dose-dependent and vary depending on individual factors such as age, gender, and overall health status. If you have concerns about your estrogen levels or any related symptoms, it is recommended that you consult a medical professional for a comprehensive evaluation and treatment advice.
231: Patient: My mother has severe phlegm/mucus, resulting in respiratory difficulties. The doctor recommended a tablet called Montegate and syrup called Prospan, as well as a respiratory pump, but she has not found any relief yet. We often have to nebulize her. She has been suffering for approximately a month and twice we have been to the professor level doctor in Pakistan. Besides, mucosolvan syrup is not available in Pakistan.
232:
Patient: I had upper wisdom extraction yesterday. Followed the 24 hour rule. Felt like there was a scab, thought that was the blood clot. After eating yogurt, I put water in my mouth and lightly shook my head to swish water. Is the scab feeling gone? There is a red spot at the site, but I don't know what a clot looks like, or if that little swish dislodged the clot. Should I be worried?

Doctor: After upper wisdom extraction, it is normal to have some degree of bleeding and discomfort at the extraction site. The 24 hour rule you mentioned may refer to the recommendation to avoid certain activities or foods for 24 hours after the procedure to reduce the risk of bleeding or other complications.

If you felt like there was a scab at the extraction site, it is likely due to minor bleeding and coagulation. However, it is important to distinguish between a scab and a blood clot. A blood clot usually appears as a larger area of bleeding under the gum tissue, while a scab is usually a small piece of dried blood on the surface of the gum.

If you lightly shook your head to swish water after eating yogurt, this may have dislodged the scab or blood clot. If this is the case, you may notice some bleeding or discomfort at the site. However, if the bleeding is minor and stops quickly, it is usually not necessary to be overly worried.

If there is a red spot at the site but no obvious bleeding or discomfort, it may be due to minor inflammation or irritation. This usually resolves on its own over time.

If you are concerned about the possibility of dislodging a clot or have any other concerns, it is recommended to consult your dentist for professional diagnosis and treatment advice. They can examine your mouth and provide guidance on whether further treatment or observation is necessary.
233:
Hello, as a doctor, I can answer your medical questions.

First of all, let me explain what PCOS is. PCOS, or polycystic ovarian syndrome, is a common endocrine disorder that can cause irregular menstruation, ovulation problems, and often leads to facial hair growth.

Ginette35 is a type of birth control pill that can help reduce facial hair growth in women with PCOS by regulating hormone levels. It can be effective in reducing facial hair growth, but the time it takes to see results varies from person to person. Typically, you may see results after taking the medication for a few months. However, it may take some time to fully evaluate the effectiveness of the medication, and in some cases, other treatment options may be recommended.

UPROOT LOTION is a type of lotion that contains ingredients that can help remove facial hair. It can be effective in reducing the appearance of facial hair, but again, the time it takes to see results varies from person to person. Typically, you may see results after using the lotion for a few weeks, but it may take longer for significant results.

Both Ginette35 and UPROOT LOTION can be effective in reducing facial hair growth in women with PCOS, but the time it takes to see results varies. It is important to continue using the medication or lotion as directed and to avoid missing any doses to ensure maximum effectiveness. Additionally, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider regularly to monitor your progress and adjust the treatment plan if necessary.

I hope this information helps you. If you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to ask me.

235:

236: Hello, the appearance of worm-like veins near the hairline and temples, especially if they are painful and have grown in size, is a concerning symptom that requires medical attention. 237:
Patient: okay, here goes: my 9 month old nephew's mother just found a lump under the skin of her son. He is an otherwise healthy baby and saw his pediatrician 2 days ago. He is scheduled for a c-t scan tomorrow. Can you provide any info re: how common this is, what it may be, and how likely is it that it is something serious? Thank you so much.

Doctor: It is important to determine the cause of the lump under the skin of your nephew. While it can be alarming, it is important to remember that lumps are common in infants and young children. They can be caused by a variety of reasons, including cysts, fatty deposits, and benign growths. However, it is always important to investigate any new lump or changes in the skin to rule out any potential health concerns.

Your nephew has already been scheduled for a CT scan, which will provide valuable information about the lump and its location. The CT scan will help the pediatrician determine if the lump is causing any internal issues or if it is in a location that could be concerning.

The likelihood of the lump being serious depends on the findings from the CT scan and the physical examination by the pediatrician. If the lump is soft, movable, and painless, it is more likely to be benign. However, if the lump is firm, irregular, or accompanied by other symptoms, it may require further evaluation to rule out any potential health concerns.

It is important to remember that even if the lump is benign, it should be monitored closely by your nephew's pediatrician to ensure that there are no changes or complications. If your nephew's pediatrician identifies any concerning features or if the lump persists or increases in size, they may recommend additional testing or referral to a specialist for further evaluation.

In summary, while lumps are common in infants and young children, it is important to investigate any new lump or changes in the skin to rule out any potential health concerns. Your nephew's CT scan and follow-up with his pediatrician will provide valuable information about the cause and nature of the lump.
238:
Patient: Hi, while I was jogging, after about 4km or 2.5 miles, I started walking and suddenly got severe back pain and could not take deep breaths. Bending over helped a little bit and it passed after a couple of minutes. I have asthma but take Forair twice a day, which keeps it under control. I am not very fit, just started running. Any help will be great. Thank you.

Doctor: It sounds like you may have experienced a brief episode of exercise-induced asthma (EIA) or exercise-induced bronchospasm (EIB). This can occur in people with asthma when they engage in physical activity, causing the airways to narrow and making it difficult to breathe.

The symptoms you described - severe back pain and difficulty taking deep breaths - are consistent with EIB. The bending over position may have helped to open up the airways slightly, which could explain why the symptoms improved after a few minutes.

To help manage this condition, it's important to maintain good asthma control by using your Forair inhaler regularly as prescribed. If your symptoms persist or become more severe, it's essential to seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor can adjust your treatment plan and provide additional guidance on managing EIB effectively.

It's also important to gradually introduce physical activity into your routine to avoid more severe symptoms. Start with low-intensity activities and gradually increase the intensity over time. If you experience any symptoms during exercise, stop immediately and take necessary steps to recover, such as using your inhaler and gradually reducing activity level.

Please note that this is not a substitute for professional medical advice. It's essential to consult your doctor for a comprehensive evaluation and personalized treatment plan.
243:
As a doctor, I cannot provide a direct answer on whether Jo-Anna can undergo knee surgery based on the information provided. However, based on the information given, it appears that her resting heart rate of 37 may be considered low, and the hospital is concerned about this.

If Jo-Anna has no symptoms of shortness of breath, fatigue, etc., then it may not be an immediate concern. However, it is important to evaluate her heart function and ensure that it is normal. This can be done by a cardiologist who can perform tests to assess her heart rate, rhythm, and blood pressure.

If Jo-Anna's heart function is normal and the surgery is necessary, then the surgery can be performed. However, if there are any concerns about her heart function, then the surgery may need to be postponed until further evaluation and treatment.

I suggest that Jo-Anna follows the advice of the hospital and sees a cardiologist for further evaluation. The cardiologist will be able to assess her heart function and provide guidance on whether the surgery can be safely performed.
244:
Based on your description, your symptoms may be related to the cleaning solution your mother-in-law is using. Pine-sol and Clorox are strong cleaning agents that can irritate the respiratory system and cause coughing, difficulty breathing, and wheezing.

If your symptoms are mild and temporary, it may be appropriate to avoid further exposure to the cleaning solution and observe your symptoms. However, if your symptoms are severe or persistent, it is recommended to seek medical attention promptly. A doctor can evaluate your symptoms and recommend appropriate treatment measures.

In addition, it is important to remind your family members of the potential health risks associated with using strong cleaning agents and to consider alternative cleaning methods that are less irritating to the respiratory system.
245:
Patient: I have been on treatment for high prolactin levels (100ng/ml), which later lowered to 65ng/ml 5 months ago. I have been having unprotected intercourse (trying to conceive) for the past 14 months. My periods appear every 35 days, but the last one was 4 days late and it came as soon as we had intercourse with my husband. Is there a chance that I could conceive soon?

Doctor: Based on your description, your prolactin levels have been controlled and are currently within the normal range. However, it is important to note that prolactin levels alone do not determine fertility. Fertility is also affected by other factors such as ovulation, egg quality, sperm quality, and the health of the uterus and fallopian tubes.

From your description, your periods are appearing every 35 days, which is within the normal range. However, if your period was 4 days late and came as soon as you had intercourse with your husband, it may suggest that you were experiencing some form of fertile cervical mucus.

The likelihood of conceiving soon is difficult to determine as it varies from person to person. Fertility can be affected by many factors, including age, lifestyle habits, and underlying health conditions. If you are concerned about your fertility, it is recommended that you consult a fertility specialist for a comprehensive evaluation and individualized advice.

In the meantime, continue to have regular unprotected intercourse during your fertile window (usually calculated from the day of ovulation to the day before the next period). Additionally, maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoidance of harmful substances such as alcohol and smoking.

Remember, fertility is a complex process that requires time and patience. If you are experiencing any concerns or difficulties, it is important to seek professional advice promptly.
247:
Hello Aubrey,

Thank you for sharing your two health concerns with me. Let's address them one by one.

1. Curvature of the spine and narrow shoulders:

Exercise plays a vital role in maintaining good posture and developing wide shoulders. Here are a few suggestions to help you widen your shoulders and straighten your spine:

Barbell shrug: This exercise targets the trapezius muscles, which are responsible for raising your shoulders. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a barbell with both hands and let it rest on your thighs. Shrug your shoulders up towards your ears and hold for a second. Then lower them back to the starting position. Repeat 3 sets of 10-12 reps.

Deadlift: This exercise strengthens your back, hips, and legs while promoting good posture. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hands by your sides. Bend your knees slightly and lower your body towards the floor, keeping your back flat and chest up. As you lower your body, grab the barbell with both hands and squeeze your glutes. Raise your body back to the starting position, holding the barbell close to your body. Repeat 3 sets of 10-12 reps.

Yoga: Yoga can help improve flexibility and balance while strengthening your core and back muscles. Try practicing poses like downward-facing dog, upward-facing dog, and cobra pose. These poses help lengthen the spine and open the shoulders.

2. Permanent blocked nose and facial swelling:

This could be due to various reasons such as allergies, sinusitis, or structural issues with the nose. Here are a few things you can try:

Allergies: If you are allergic to certain substances like pollen or dust mites, you may experience nasal blockage and facial swelling. It's important to identify and avoid the allergen. If possible, get tested for allergies to identify the specific triggers.

Sinusitis: Blocked sinuses can lead to facial swelling and nasal blockage. Saline nasal irrigation can help clear out the sinuses and relieve congestion. Mix a quarter teaspoon of salt with 8 ounces of warm water. Use a neti pot or bulb syringe to gently irrigate each nostril with the saline solution.

Nasal passage narrowing: Some people have a naturally narrow nasal passage that can contribute to nasal blockage. Simple lifestyle changes like avoiding sleeping on your back or using a pillow that doesn't compress your neck can help improve airflow through the nose.

Breathing through your mouth: If you are used to breathing through your mouth, it can lead to dry mouth, which can contribute to nasal blockage. Try to train yourself to breathe through your nose, as it provides a more humidified and filtered supply of air. Practice nasal breathing by pursing your lips and inhaling through your nose deeply. Hold your breath for a few seconds, then exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat several times daily.

If you experience any discomfort or concerns, it's important to consult a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment recommendations.

255:
Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on the information you have provided, your brother has been diagnosed with Hepatitis A and is currently admitted to Manipal Hospital in Bangalore. His bilirubin count remains high at 30, and he is experiencing scratching all over his body. MRCP results were normal, and the doctors are confused about the cause of his symptoms. They have suggested performing an endoscopy to investigate further.

Hepatitis A is a liver infection caused by the Hepatitis A virus. It can cause elevated bilirubin levels, which is a by-product of liver cells breaking down. High bilirubin levels can lead to jaundice, a yellowing of the skin and eyes.

The scratching all over his body could be a side effect of the Hepatitis A infection or may be related to high bilirubin levels. It could also be caused by other conditions, such as allergies or skin diseases.

Endoscopy is a procedure that allows doctors to visualize the inside of the digestive tract using a small camera. It can help identify any abnormalities or lesions that may be causing the symptoms. Endoscopy may also be useful in collecting samples for further testing, such as biopsies, to rule out any other possible conditions.

It is important to follow the advice of your brother's doctors and proceed with the endoscopy as recommended. The doctors will review the results and use their expertise to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for your brother. If you have any further questions or concerns, it is recommended to discuss them with your brother's treating team.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your concerns. It's important to bring any concerns or changes in your child's health to the attention of a healthcare professional. The ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) test measures the rate at which red blood cells sediment in a test tube. It can be used as a general screening test for inflammatory conditions, but it's not specific for any particular condition.

Based on your description, your daughter has a raised lump in her neck which you suspect may be a gland. This could be an indicator of a number of conditions, such as an enlarged lymph node, thyroid gland issue, or other benign conditions. However, it's important to conduct further evaluations to determine the cause of the lump.

I suggest scheduling a follow-up appointment with the doctor who performed the blood test. They will be able to review the ESR results and conduct a physical examination to assess the lump and recommend any necessary tests or referrals to a specialist if necessary.

In the meantime, continue to monitor your daughter's symptoms and ensure she avoids any activities that may increase the risk of injury to the neck area. If her symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact the doctor's office.

Please take the necessary steps to schedule a follow-up appointment soon to ensure your daughter receives appropriate care.

Yes, if your follicle ruptured yesterday, you still have a chance of getting pregnant. The release of the egg from the follicle is just one part of the process of fertilization. After the egg is released, it can be fertilized by sperm for up to 24 hours. Therefore, if your doctor recommended having intercourse tonight and tomorrow night, it is correct. This will increase the chances of fertilization if your egg has not already been fertilized.

However, it is important to note that even if your follicle ruptured and you had intercourse, there is no guarantee that you will become pregnant. Fertilization and pregnancy are affected by many factors, including the health of the egg and sperm, the timing of ovulation, and the ability of the uterus to support pregnancy.

If you are concerned about your fertility and want to increase your chances of pregnancy, it is recommended that you and your husband seek advice from a fertility specialist. They can provide you with more accurate guidance on how to optimize your fertility and increase your chances of becoming pregnant.
