265:
Hello Dharmender, 

It is good to hear from you. When it comes to treating rheumatoid arthritis, there are three main types of treatment: allopathic, homeopathic, and Ayurvedic. Each one has its own benefits and potential drawbacks. 

1. Allopathic Treatment: 
Allopathy is the most commonly used form of treatment in the Western world. It involves the use of drugs to reduce inflammation and pain, and to slow the progression of the disease. Drugs like corticosteroids, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs), and biologics are commonly used. 

Pros: 

* Fast acting: Drugs can quickly reduce inflammation and pain. 
* Scientific basis: Allopathic drugs are typically backed by extensive scientific research. 
* Availability: Allopathic drugs are widely available, and many insurance plans cover them. 

Cons: 

* Side effects: Allopathic drugs can have significant side effects, including but not limited to nausea, vomiting, stomach ulcers, liver damage, and increased risk of infection. 
* Dependency: Some patients may become dependent on these drugs, and stopping them may result in a flare-up of symptoms. 
* Cost: Biologics and other advanced drugs can be very expensive. 
2. Homeopathic Treatment: 
Homeopathy is a form of alternative medicine that uses extremely small doses of substances to stimulate the body's own healing mechanisms. It is based on the belief that "like cures like" - that a substance that causes symptoms in large doses can sometimes be used in small doses to treat those symptoms. 

Pros: 

* Gentle: Homeopathic treatments are generally very gentle and non-toxic. 
* Holistic: Homeopathy treats the whole person, not just the symptoms. 
* Cost: Homeopathic treatments can often be obtained at a lower cost than allopathic drugs. 

Cons: 

* Unproven: The scientific evidence for homeopathy is mixed. While some studies show positive results, many others do not. 
* Time-consuming: Homeopathic treatments may take longer to work than allopathic drugs. 
* Variable quality: The quality and effectiveness of homeopathic products can vary widely. 
3. Ayurvedic Treatment: 
Ayurveda is an ancient Indian system of medicine that focuses on balance and harmony in the body. It uses a variety of natural methods including diet, herbs, massage, and yoga to treat different diseases and conditions. Ayurveda can be used alone or in combination with other forms of treatment. 

Pros: 

* Natural: Ayurvedic treatments are all natural and often free of side effects. 
* Holistic: Ayurveda treats the whole person, not just the symptoms. It looks at the root causes of disease. 
* Cost: Ayurvedic treatments can often be obtained at a lower cost than allopathic drugs. 

Cons: 

* Unproven: The scientific evidence for Ayurvedic treatments is often limited or mixed. Some Ayurvedic practices have been shown to be effective, but others have not. 
* Time-consuming: Ayurvedic treatments may take longer to work than allopathic drugs. 
* Variable quality: The quality and effectiveness of Ayurvedic products and practices can vary widely. 
* Difficulties in finding trained practitioners: It can be challenging to find an experienced Ayurvedic practitioner in some parts of the world. 
4. Integrative Medicine: Integrative medicine combines different forms of treatment to create a personalized plan for each patient. This approach often involves using allopathic drugs when necessary but also incorporating complementary methods like homeopathy or Ayurveda to support the patient's overall health and well-being. 
  Consulting with a rheumatologist who is knowledgeable about both allopathy and complementary medicine can help guide you through this process if you choose this approach. Considerations for Integrative Medicine include the following: * The need for additional training for doctors in integrative medicine * The importance of ongoing patient education and support * The cost of integrative medicine may be higher due to the combination of different treatment methods * The potential for interactions between different treatment modalities integrative medicine is becoming increasingly popular as patients seek more personalized and comprehensive care for their rheumatoid arthritis. Talking with your doctor about your specific symptoms, medical history, and goals can help determine which approach may be best for you based on your unique situation.
266:
Hello Curtis,

I am sorry to hear about your recent surgery and the difficulties you are experiencing with food. The symptoms you are describing are quite common after abdominal surgery, particularly when large sections of the colon have been removed.

The feelings of nausea and aversion to food that you are experiencing are likely due to changes in your digestive system following the surgery. It may take several weeks for your body to adjust to these changes and for your intestines to heal properly. During this time, your sense of taste and smell may be heightened, making certain foods seem unpleasant or even repulsive.

It is important to start gradually reintroducing solid foods as soon as possible after surgery. You may find that certain foods are easier to digest than others, and that certain meals or snacks do not agree with you as well as others. It is also important to stay well-hydrated and to avoid high-fibre foods initially, as they can be difficult to digest.

If your surgeon has not already recommended a diet plan, it may be beneficial to consult with them to develop a personalized plan for gradually reintroducing food into your diet. They can monitor your progress and make adjustments to your diet as necessary.

Please do not try to force yourself to eat if you feel unable to tolerate certain foods. It is better to eat small amounts of food that agree with you and gradually increase the amount as your body adjusts.

It is also important to maintain a regular schedule of meals and snacks, even if you feel unable to eat much at each meal. Eating regular meals can help with digestion and improve tolerance of food.

Overall, it may take several weeks for your sense of taste and digestive system to normalize following surgery. It is important to take it slow and gradually increase your tolerance for food while closely monitoring your progress with your surgeon.

If your symptoms persist or if you have any concerns, it is important to contact your surgeon promptly for further evaluation and advice. They can provide you with additional support and guidance during this challenging time.

Take care and I hope that you will soon be able to return to normal eating habits again soon.

I am always short of breath, tired, and have pressure in my chest on the right side of my breastbone. Please help.

Doctor: Thank you for providing your medical history. Based on your symptoms and medication, it seems like you might be experiencing some side effects from the surgery and medication. However, it is important to conduct some tests to rule out any possible conditions, including pulmonary hypertension.

Amiodarone can cause various side effects, including irregular heartbeat, slow heartbeat, and other cardiac issues. In addition, your pulse rate is slightly elevated, which might be due to the medication or other factors. It is important to monitor your heart rate and rhythm regularly. If your heart rate remains high or if you experience any concerning symptoms, please seek medical attention promptly.

For your shortness of breath and tiredness, it might be related to the sarcoidosis or the medication. It is recommended to rest and limit physical activity until your condition improves. If the symptoms persist or worsen, please contact your doctor promptly for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.

Please note that this is not a substitute for professional medical advice. It is important to consult your doctor for a comprehensive evaluation and treatment plan specific to your condition.

Hello, Dr. Patient:

Thank you for your query. Tretinoin is a retinoid that is commonly used in the treatment of various skin conditions, including acne, wrinkles, and psoriasis. It works by regulating the cell turnover in the skin, which helps to improve the texture and elasticity of the skin.

However, like you mentioned, tretinoin can cause skin dryness and peeling, especially when used in high concentrations or for prolonged periods. Therefore, it is recommended to use tretinoin at night and avoid exposure to sunlight, as sunlight can make the skin more sensitive to tretinoin.

If you have mixed or hairy skin, you may want to consider using a lower concentration of tretinoin (e.g., 0.025%) to minimize side effects. Additionally, using a moisturizing night cream can help to counteract the dryness caused by tretinoin.

It is important to start using tretinoin gradually, and to discontinue use if any adverse reactions occur. If you have any concerns or questions, it is best to consult a dermatologist for professional advice.

Doctor: Hello, I am sorry to hear that your acne is not improving with the current treatment plan. Let's review your routine and make some suggestions to help clear up your acne and reduce the red patches.

Firstly, it's important to remember that acne takes time to clear up, and the treatment plan you are following is a common one used to control acne. However, we can make some adjustments to optimize the results.

For your morning routine, zyclin nano gel is a good choice. Continue using it as directed. But during the evening, when you apply retino A for 3 hours, it might be causing irritation or dryness on your skin, which can lead to more breakouts. We can try reducing the duration of application or reducing the frequency.

Additionally, it's essential to maintain a consistent skincare routine. Make sure to cleanse your face thoroughly before applying any medication, and use a gentle moisturizer after applying the medication to keep your skin hydrated.

To help reduce the red patches, apply a light layer of a soothing lotion or gel after applying the medication. This can help calm the skin and reduce any irritation or discoloration.

It's also important to note that while these changes may help, it's essential to continue using the medication as prescribed by your doctor until he/she advises otherwise. If your acne doesn't improve after making these changes, it's recommended to consult your doctor for further evaluation and possible adjustments to your treatment plan.

Remember, skincare is a journey, and it takes time to see significant improvements. Stick with the plan, and if you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact your doctor for further guidance.

300: Patient: Hi. For about a month, I have been feeling like something in my stomach gets knotted, causing me to bend and twist or stretch to relieve the sudden pain and discomfort. I have had this feeling before a few years back, but now it is happening to me throughout the day on a daily basis. I also have a dry cough which has made the condition worse. Sometimes I'll get a coughing fit and my stomach will suddenly knot up, which is very scary and painful because I worry that I won't get it unknotted again. Hope you can help me.
301:
Hello Ragesh Shankar,

As a doctor, I suggest that we should consider surgery for your 1-year-old and 8-month-old child's thyroglossal cyst. This type of cyst is relatively common in children and usually requires surgical removal. The surgery is generally safe and effective for children of this age.

However, before surgery, we need to perform some tests to rule out any other conditions that may be present. We will also need to discuss the risks and benefits of surgery with you and answer any of your questions.

If you have any concerns or questions about your child's condition or the surgery, please feel free to discuss them with me. I will do my best to provide you with accurate and helpful answers.
302:
Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on your description, the swollen lump on your back and the area under your breast may be due to different reasons. The swollen lump on your back may be a subcutaneous cyst or a lipoma, which is a common type of soft tissue tumor. It usually does not cause pain or discomfort and usually disappears within a few days or weeks.

The swollen area under your breast may be due to the trauma caused by the palpation during the nursing lab. This kind of trauma can cause temporary swelling and discomfort. If the pain and swelling are not severe, you can apply ice compresses or use anti-inflammatory drugs to relieve the symptoms. If the pain and swelling persist or worsen, please consult a doctor for further examination and treatment advice.

In general, these two kinds of swelling are not likely to be serious conditions. However, if you are still worried or have other symptoms, it is recommended that you consult a doctor for professional diagnosis and treatment advice. I wish you an early recovery!
303: Hello John, Amoxicillin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat a variety of bacterial infections. In your case, if you suspect a tooth infection, it is important to follow the instructions on the prescription. The recommended dosage is three times daily, on an empty stomach or with food, for seven days. However, it is important to note that Amoxicillin may have side effects such as diarrhea, nausea, and rashes. If you experience any of these side effects, it is recommended that you stop taking the medication and consult a doctor. Additionally, if your symptoms do not improve within seven days, it is recommended that you consult a doctor as well. I hope this information helps. Best regards!
304:
Hello, I am a doctor. Based on your description, your symptoms seem to indicate an infection around the wisdom tooth area, which is consistent with pericoronitis. Pericoronitis is an inflammation around the gum that covers the wisdom tooth, usually caused by a bacterial infection.

Firstly, I recommend that you take antibiotics to control the infection. If you have a fever, it is also important to take anti-fever medication. Additionally, it is important to maintain good oral hygiene by brushing and rinsing your mouth frequently.

If your symptoms do not improve after a few days of antibiotics, I suggest that you go back to the doctor for further evaluation. They may need to perform a more detailed examination and possibly take radiographs (X-rays) to better visualize the area and determine if there are any more underlying issues.

Please note that this is a general recommendation based on your symptoms. It is always best to consult a professional doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment advice.
305:
Hello, I am a doctor. Based on your description, your baby has been suffering from fever, cough, and cold since yesterday. You have given him crocin syrup, which helped reduce the fever, and levolin syrup yesterday, which helped relieve the cough. However, after taking azithral 100 this morning, the cough worsened. I suggest that you should not give him any medication at this time.

If the baby's condition does not improve, I suggest that you consult a doctor for professional diagnosis and treatment advice.
306:
Based on your description, it seems like your son has been experiencing symptoms of a fever, headache, and eye soreness for three days. He also complains of eye burning and sensitivity to light, and looking down hurts. These symptoms could potentially indicate an eye infection or other health issues that should be evaluated by a doctor.

I recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. A doctor can perform a comprehensive examination to assess the cause of your son's symptoms and provide appropriate treatment advice. It is important to take prompt action if there are concerns about the possibility of a more serious condition, such as an eye infection that may require antibiotics or other treatment.

If your son's symptoms are not severe and he is otherwise stable, you can consider waiting another day or two before seeking medical attention. However, if his symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns about his condition, it is important to seek medical attention promptly.

In the meantime, you can help manage your son's symptoms by giving him over-the-counter pain relievers for the headache and soreness, and providing him with plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. If his symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention promptly.
309: Patient: I have had dizziness, which seems to be vertigo, for 6 days now. Nausea, vomiting if I move too fast. Extreme exhaustion. Numbness in right arm, or bad circulation. Pain in the back of my neck that seemed to start before all of this, which I thought was from stress.
310:
Bilateral mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bones, which are located behind the ears and help protect the inner ear and the nerves related to hearing. The condition can cause pain, tenderness, and swelling in the mastoid area.

The antibiotics your doctor prescribed are designed to treat the infection. If the antibiotics don't work, surgery may be necessary to drain the infected mastoid bone.

The good news is that with treatment, the prognosis for bilateral mastoiditis is usually good. However, it's important to follow your doctor's advice and make sure your child completes the course of antibiotics. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to contact your doctor's office for more information.
311:
Patient: I was told on Friday that I have thyroid cancer. I am terrified. Is there anything I can do until I see the endocrinologist? Will I need surgery or chemo? I am 47 years old and have gained 16 pounds in 2 months. I have been a health nut for 25 years and have always been in great shape, eat right, etc. Why do I have this?

Doctor: First of all, don't panic. Cancer is a treatable condition, and we will do everything we can to help you.

Until you see the endocrinologist, it is important to manage your stress levels and anxiety. Try to relax and take deep breaths. Avoid googling or reading about thyroid cancer as this may increase your anxiety.

As for your questions, surgery is often recommended for thyroid cancer, but the type of surgery required depends on the extent of the cancer and your overall health. Chemotherapy is typically reserved for more advanced cases, but it may be considered in some situations.

Your age and health habits may be factors that contributed to the development of thyroid cancer. However, the exact cause is often unknown. It is important to note that even if you have a strong health history, anyone can develop cancer.

When you see the endocrinologist, they will provide a more detailed diagnosis and treatment plan. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any other questions or concerns.
315: Hello, patient. It is important to immediately seek medical attention after being bitten by a dog, even if the dog has been previously vaccinated. Anti-rabies vaccination is crucial to prevent the virus from spreading and should be given as soon as possible. It is recommended to receive the anti-rabies vaccine within 24 hours of being bitten. Additionally, tetanus vaccination is also recommended to prevent tetanus infection. Your mom's advice to receive the anti-rabies vaccine three days after the bite may not be sufficient to prevent rabies effectively. It is crucial to seek medical attention promptly and receive the necessary vaccinations as soon as possible.
317: As a doctor, I cannot provide a final diagnosis without examining the patient, but based on the information you have provided, it seems like the lump in your left butt cheek may have enlarged over the past 6 months. This could be a cause for concern. It is recommended that you consult a doctor for a follow-up examination and a detailed assessment of the lump. The doctor will examine the lump, conduct necessary tests, and determine the nature of the lump. If necessary, the doctor may recommend further testing or treatment. It is important to seek medical attention promptly to ensure that any potential health issues are addressed promptly.
318:
Hello Helen, 
 
The appearance of a golf ball-sized lump at the top of the spine can be a cause for concern, as it could potentially indicate a variety of conditions. Cysts are a possibility, but they are not always the most likely diagnosis. Other possible conditions include abscesses, enlarged lymph nodes, and even tumors. 
 
Given the painful nature of the lump and your friend's daughter's report of headaches, it would be advisable to seek medical attention as soon as possible. A thorough examination by a doctor is necessary to determine the exact nature of the lump and to rule out any potential health issues. 
 
It's important not to self-diagnose or attempt to treat the lump without professional advice. The best course of action is to contact your doctor or a healthcare provider as soon as possible to schedule an evaluation and determine the next steps in management. 
 
I hope this information is helpful. Please pass on my recommendations to your friend.
319:
Hello Mark,

Based on your symptoms and description, it seems like you might be experiencing an inflammation of the gums, possibly due to gingivitis or another gum infection. I would recommend the following steps to help relieve the inflammation and pain:

1. Antibiotics: If your dentist is not available and you have a prescription for antibiotics, take them as directed to help reduce the infection.
2. NSAIDs (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs): You can take over-the-counter NSAIDs like ibuprofen or acetaminophen to help relieve the pain and inflammation.
3. Salt Water Rinse: Continue using salt water to rinse your mouth several times a day. This can help reduce the inflammation and provide some temporary relief.
4. Extra Hygiene: Brushing your teeth twice a day is good, but you can also use a soft-bristled toothbrush and extra gentle brushing techniques to avoid further irritation of the gums.
5. Avoid Irritants: Avoid any irritants like alcohol, tobacco, and spicy or acidic foods that may further irritate the gums.
6. Temperature Sensitive Foods: Eat food at room temperature to avoid temperature extremes that may irritate the gums.
7. Apply Pressure: Apply cold compresses to the swollen gum area for 10-15 minutes several times a day to help reduce the inflammation and pain.
8. Call Your Dentist: It's important to contact your dentist as soon as possible to schedule an appointment for a thorough examination and treatment advice.

Please note that these are temporary measures to help relieve your symptoms until you can see a dentist. If your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns, please seek medical attention promptly.
320: Patient: Thank you. The day before yesterday, a cast iron lamp fell off a shelf and hit me with a force. The pain is really bad. It did not bleed. I have several big knots on my head and it is like a very dark red and I have a dent in my head. So I am tired and today I have diarrhea. I am not sure what to do. I can not touch my head. The size is bigger than half of a dollar.
322: Hello, I am a doctor. Based on your description, I suggest that you continue to take the amlodipine besylate/atrivastatin calcium tablets and atenolol tablets, but you need to monitor your blood pressure and heart rate regularly.
