427:
Patient: My 4-month-old nephew has always had a yellowish tint to his skin, but now his eyes and skin are very yellow. He is currently in the hospital. He has an enlarged liver and spleen, blood in his stool, very thin blood, and has developed a heart murmur. They say that his organs are beginning to turn yellow. They cannot figure out what is wrong. Any ideas?

Doctor: Based on your description, your nephew's condition sounds very serious. The yellow tint to his skin, yellow eyes, enlarged liver and spleen, blood in the stool, very thin blood, and a heart murmur are all concerning signs.

It sounds like he may have a liver disease or a genetic disorder that is affecting his organs. The yellowing of his skin and organs is usually a result of a buildup of bilirubin, a byproduct of red blood cells that the liver normally processes and excretes.

Some possible causes of his symptoms include biliary atresia, a condition where the bile ducts in the liver are blocked or absent, causing bilirubin to accumulate, and kernicterus, a rare but serious condition where there is a buildup of bilirubin in the brain.

He should be evaluated by a pediatric hepatologist or a geneticist as soon as possible to determine the cause of his symptoms and to receive appropriate treatment. In the meantime, it is important to ensure that he is receiving appropriate supportive care, including fluids and electrolytes, to maintain his overall health.

Please seek medical advice for your nephew as soon as possible and follow the recommendations of the doctors who are caring for him.
428:
Patient: Hi, my wife noticed a huge bruise on the inside of my right leg, about 5 to 6 inches in diameter. It had a large lump in the middle and then started to go away in an odd way. A bruise usually fades all at once but this one starting fading from the inside and is now almost in the shape of the letter C. I have no recollection of hitting my leg at all, it just showed up as far as I can remember. The lump still remains. Any ideas on what this could be?

Doctor: When a bruise does not fade as expected or takes an unusual shape, it can be concerning. However, without additional information, it is difficult to provide a specific diagnosis. It is important to see a healthcare provider for a proper evaluation. They will be able to examine the bruise and lump, consider your history, and determine if further testing or treatment is necessary. Please seek medical attention promptly to ensure your health is properly managed.
429:
Patient: I have palpitations in my left thigh for about two hours now, but this is an ongoing problem for the last two or three months. Usually, either in my left upper arm or my left thigh, before the palpitations, I get a chest pain. What could this be?

Doctor: It sounds like you may be experiencing some heart-related issues. Palpitations are often a sign of irregular heartbeat, which can be caused by a variety of reasons. Chest pain can also be a symptom of heart disease or other cardiac conditions.

To accurately diagnose your condition, I would recommend that you see a cardiologist for a thorough examination and heart testing. They will be able to assess your symptoms and determine the cause of your palpitations and chest pain.

Please take this seriously and seek medical attention promptly. Heart-related issues can be serious and require prompt treatment.
430:
Hello Sara, I'm sorry to hear about your recent ultrasound results. It is concerning that your baby's growth seems to be lagging behind. Miscarriage is a very difficult experience, and it is important to take care of your physical and emotional health during this time.

Firstly, it is important to confirm the viability of the pregnancy. If the sac size is smaller than expected, it could be a sign of an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is not developing normally. It is essential to monitor the pregnancy closely and seek medical advice promptly.

If the pregnancy is viable, but the fetus is not growing as expected, there are certain measures that can be taken to promote fetal growth. Firstly, it is essential to ensure that you are getting enough rest and reducing any stress or anxiety that may be affecting your health. Eating a balanced diet with plenty of protein and healthy fats can also help support fetal growth.

In some cases, doctors may recommend the use of low-dose aspirin or progesterone supplements to help support fetal growth and reduce the risk of miscarriage. However, these measures should only be prescribed by a doctor after a thorough evaluation of your case.

It is essential to continue monitoring the pregnancy closely through serial ultrasounds and blood tests. If there are any signs of bleeding, pain, or other complications, it is important to seek medical attention immediately.

Please take care of yourself and seek medical advice promptly. I wish you the best with your pregnancy and hope for a healthy outcome for you and your baby.
434:
Endocrinologists can make predictions about female final height from age 7, but these predictions are not always accurate. Growth and development are highly individualized, and many factors can affect a child's final height, including genetics, nutrition, and health conditions.

In your daughter's case, the endocrinologist may want to continue to see her because he wants to monitor her growth and development. This is especially true if her growth rate is unusually high or if there is a family history of early puberty or tall stature. Monitoring her growth and development over time will help the endocrinologist assess whether her growth is normal or whether there may be any underlying health conditions that need to be addressed.

It is important to remember that the endocrinologist's predictions about your daughter's final height are just that - predictions. Your daughter's actual final height may vary from these predictions. The best thing you can do is provide your daughter with a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and regular exercise, as these are key factors in promoting healthy growth and development.
435:
Patient: Hi, I'm 13 and I think I have a clinical/major depression disorder. I have only told one of my best friends about 3 days ago. I want help but I have some problems in my way. I think my parents will think I'm lying for attention or something. Also, I would like a little more confidence in that I might have it or not. (This all started with me just feeling sad for no reason for a good amount of time, and then I took some online tests, which all said I had depression and I read more about it. And I have almost all the symptoms.) I just would like your opinion if I should go see a doctor and if I should tell my parents. By the way, no one in my close family has any type of depression. I would love your feelings, Thanks!

Doctor: Hello, as a professional doctor, I understand your concerns and would like to provide you with some advice. If you believe that you may have clinical depression, it is recommended that you seek professional medical attention as soon as possible. A doctor can conduct a comprehensive evaluation and provide you with appropriate treatment recommendations.

Regarding whether you should tell your parents, this is a personal decision. However, it is important to remember that depression is a common mental health problem and there is no need to feel embarrassed or guilty about it. Your parents may be able to provide support and assistance to you, and it is recommended that you choose a suitable time and manner to communicate with them.

Finally, remember that mental health problems are not something to be ashamed of or hidden. It is important to seek help and support as soon as possible, and to maintain a positive attitude towards treatment and recovery. I wish you a speedy recovery.
436:
Patient: Hi, I am a 17-year-old female and I always feel these liquid sensations moving through my brain. I can hear them and it is like water swishing for about 1-4 seconds. This occurs multiple times a week and I frequently feel a lot of pressure on my head. Occasionally, I will get this sudden cold, tingly, numbing rush that overtakes the left side of my body. The moving liquid sensations occurs on the right, upper back side of my head. Can you help identify what the issue is?

Doctor: Hello, based on your description, it seems like you might be experiencing some sort of mild cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) disturbance or aural vestibular schwannoma (AVS). However, it is important to note that this is just a possible diagnosis and it requires further testing and evaluation by a medical professional. Please consult a neurologist as soon as possible to get a more accurate diagnosis and treatment advice.

Sometimes my vaginal area is a little sore the next day after being sexually active, but this time it is different. I have also felt little bumps or ridges inside my vagina. My discharge smells and looks normal except when I apply itch cream to it, then it becomes a little thicker and whiter. My boyfriend is completely fine with no irritation to his genitals. We tried having sex again a day after I noticed the pain, and there was a very sharp pain when he tried to enter that nearly left me crying in pain. There is some burning during urination, but I think that only happens when I have been scratching the area. 439:
Patient: I have elevated liver enzymes. On Dr. recommendation, I stopped drinking completely for 5 weeks and took the blood test again, but the levels were the same, actually a little higher. How long does it take to reverse the fat levels? I am 70 years old, no symptoms other than these levels and used to drink two drinks a day for as long as I can remember. I was surprised the level did not go down after 5 weeks of being so good. Could something else be causing it?

Doctor: Elevated liver enzymes can be caused by various factors, including alcohol abuse, fatty liver, hepatitis, and other conditions. In your case, if you have stopped drinking completely for 5 weeks but the levels remain the same, it may suggest that the elevated enzymes are not caused by alcohol abuse. It could be due to other factors such as fatty liver, hepatitis, or other conditions.

It usually takes time for the liver to recover and reverse the effects of alcohol abuse or other conditions that cause elevated enzymes. However, the time it takes for the liver to recover varies from person to person. In your case, as you are 70 years old, it may take longer for your liver to recover.

If your doctor has not found any other cause of the elevated enzymes, it is recommended that you continue to avoid alcohol and other hepatotoxic substances to protect your liver. It is also recommended that you maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and appropriate exercise, to support your liver recovery.

If your symptoms or laboratory results worsen or if you have any concerns, please consult your doctor for further evaluation and treatment advice.
440:
Based on the transvaginal ultrasound-HSSG results, your uterus and ovaries appear to be normal in size and shape. The uterus is retroverted, which means it is tilted towards the back, but it has a regular contour and inhomogeneous myometrium. The subendometrial halo is intact, which suggests that there are no adhesions or fibroids present.

Your cervix appears to be normal, with a homogenous echotexture. The endometrium is thin, hypoechoic, and compatible with the proliferative phase of your menstrual cycle.

Both ovaries are present and normal in size, with folices (follicles) within. No abnormalities are detected.

The HSSG-Remarks section mentions that both tubes are not visualized pre-instillation, but on fluid instillation with normal saline, there is spillage of fluid from both tubes with pooling of fluid around both adnexal areas and the cul-de-sac post instillation. Total fluids instilled were 25cc Saline infusion (15cc) in the endometrial cavity, which showed no pathology.

The conclusion section indicates that you have a normal-sized retroverted uterus with thin, intact endometrium, normal-sized ovaries with folicles in the right, patent fallopian tubes bilaterally, and no free fluid in the cul-de-sac.

Based on the results of your ultrasound, it appears that you still have a chance of becoming pregnant. However, the age factor can play a role in fertility, and as you age, your chances of becoming pregnant may decrease.

To increase your chances of becoming pregnant, you can consider the following steps:

1. Ovulation tracking: Use ovulation tracking methods such as basal body temperature (BBT) charting or ovulation kits to determine when you are ovulating. This can help you plan sexual intercourse during the optimal time for fertilization.
2. Lifestyle changes: Make lifestyle changes that can improve fertility, such as losing weight if you are overweight, quitting smoking, and reducing alcohol intake.
3. Consider fertility treatment: If you have been trying to conceive for a long time without success, you may want to consider fertility treatment options such as IVF (in vitro fertilization) or intrauterine insemination (IUI). These treatments can help increase your chances of pregnancy.

It is important to discuss your fertility options with a reproductive endocrinologist or fertility specialist who can provide you with more personalized advice and guidance based on your specific situation and ultrasound results.
444:
Hi Zulfiqar, I'm sorry to hear about your health issues. It sounds like you may be experiencing a fungal infection near your stomach, which can indeed cause symptoms like the ones you're describing. However, it's important to get a proper diagnosis and treatment plan from a healthcare professional.

445:
As a doctor, it is difficult to hear about your son's struggles. It is important to find a doctor that your son connects with and feels comfortable with. It could take some time to find the right doctor or treatment program, but it is important to keep searching.

Some possible options for your son could include:

1. Seeking a new treatment program: There are many different types of treatment programs available, including ones that focus on anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. It may take some research to find the right program, but it could be worth it.

2. Finding a support group: There are support groups available for people with mental health issues and their families. These groups can provide support and resources to help your son and family cope with the challenges of mental illness.

3. Exploring alternative treatments: Some people find that alternative treatments, such as cognitive behavioral therapy, mindfulness, or acupuncture, can help with their symptoms. It may be worth exploring these options with your son.

5. Seeking a second opinion: If your son's current doctors are not providing the support he needs, it may be worth seeking a second opinion from another doctor or treatment center.

I hope these suggestions can help you and your son find the right treatment option. Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.
446:
Patient: Hi doctor, I get this Herpes simplex once or twice in a year. I have noticed that this happens when I take a long journey or strain my body physically. My lower lip swells around the blister and makes me very uncomfortable. Please suggest a medicine available in India which can give me relief from swelling and pain instantly.

Doctor: Hello, Herpes simplex is a common viral infection that can cause blisters and sores on the lips, mouth, and face. It often recurs in some people. To relieve the symptoms, you can use topical antiviral agents such as Acyclovir or Famciclovir. These agents can be applied directly to the affected area and can shorten the duration of the infection and relieve the symptoms. Please note that these medications are not available over the counter in India, so you may need to consult a doctor or pharmacy for further assistance. Additionally, taking oral antiviral agents such as Valacyclovir or Famciclovir can also be effective in treating Herpes simplex infections. These agents are available in India and can be prescribed by a doctor. Please ensure that you complete the course of treatment as prescribed to ensure complete relief from the infection.
447:
Patient: I have on c5-c6 central disc protrusion/extrusion measuring 4mm AP in combination with more dorsal lateral posterior ostteophytic spurring results in severe central canal stenosis. No frank spinal cord compression or cord edema. Moderate right neural foramina narrowing and mild left left neural foramina narrowing are present due to uncovertebral hypertrophy. C6c7 posterior disc osteophyte complex results in moderate to severe central canal stenosis. Near complete attenuation of CSF around cord is present. Moderate left neural foraminal narrowing and mild right neural foraminal narrowing are present. Neurologist said I need surgery right away. Is surgery my only option?

Doctor: 

Based on the MRI results, it appears that you have severe central canal stenosis at the C5-C6 level due to disc protrusion/extrusion and osteophyte spurring. The Neurologist's recommendation for surgery is a reasonable one, considering the severity of the stenosis and the potential risk of further compression or damage to the spinal cord.

However, it is important to consider all treatment options before making a decision about surgery. Other non-surgical options may include conservative treatment such as physical therapy, NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) for pain relief, and gabapentin or pregabalin for neuropathic pain. If the conservative treatment options fail to provide significant relief, then surgery may be necessary.

Surgery is typically recommended when the stenosis is severe and there is risk of cord compression or damage. The surgery would typically involve a discectomy (removal of the protruding disc material) and a foraminotomy (opening of the neural foramina to relieve pressure on the nerves). Osteophyte removal may also be necessary to restore foraminal size and improve foraminal stenosis.

It is important to discuss all treatment options with your Neurologist and get a second opinion if necessary. Make sure you understand the risks and benefits of both surgical and non-surgical treatments so that you can make an informed decision about your treatment plan.
449:
As a doctor, I can tell you that Demetia, also known as dementia, is a cognitive impairment that can affect a person's memory, thinking, and judgment. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including Alzheimer's disease, stroke, and other brain injuries or diseases.

Regarding the effect of a severe shock on Demetia, it is possible that a severe emotional shock or stress can contribute to the onset or worsening of cognitive impairment. However, it is important to note that the relationship between Demetia and severe shock is complex and not fully understood.

If you or someone you know is experiencing cognitive impairment, it is important to seek medical attention promptly. A comprehensive evaluation by a healthcare professional can help determine the cause of the cognitive changes and provide appropriate treatment options.
450:

Is this gallbladder related to what's going on with my liver? I had cancer, is this cloudy a possibility of cancer? Ok, never mind my question. I didn't know it wasn't free hahahaha. Thank you very much bye.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your scan results and providing your medical history. Based on your description, the cloudy appearance of your liver could be due to a variety of reasons. Gallbladder removal is a separate procedure from the liver, so it is unlikely that the gallbladder removal is directly related to the liver condition.

Regarding your question about cancer, a cloudy appearance on the scan does not automatically indicate cancer. However, it is important to conduct further tests to determine the exact cause of the liver condition. It could be a fatty liver, infection, or other non-cancerous conditions.

It is recommended to follow up with your doctor and discuss the results of your scan. They will likely recommend additional tests, such as a liver biopsy or blood tests, to help determine the specific cause of the liver condition.

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any further questions or concerns. Take care!
451: Hello, patient. I am a doctor. According to your description, you had surgery for liposarcoma on your left thigh region 4-5 years ago, and now you feel tenderness in the area. There are several things you can do. First, it is recommended that you go to the hospital for a comprehensive examination and diagnosis to determine the cause of the tenderness. Second, you should consult a doctor to discuss your previous medical history, current symptoms, and possible causes of tenderness. If necessary, the doctor may recommend additional tests, such as imaging examination or tissue biopsy, to exclude the possibility of recurrence or metastasis of the tumor. Finally, it is important to follow the doctor's advice and treatment plan to ensure early detection and treatment of any possible problems. I hope this information can help you. If you have any other questions, please feel free to ask me.
452:
Patient: "Dear Madam, My wife has a regular period of 28 days. It is 28th day today she had a mild light discharge of bleeding. She is very sensitive to allergic conditions. We had intercourse from 9th Day to 16th day, she use to sneeze a lot usually after getting up in the morning. But today after the discharge at around 3 PM in the afternoon, she sneezed a lot and seem to have a little pain in the lower abdomen. Then after some time she does not have the pain. We are very hesitated to take any antihistamines like, Levo cetirizine/ cetirizine/ loratadine, which ENT doctors have prescribed. We have yet to take a ChatDoctor test. Will this sneezing cause any problems? Can you please advice us..."

Doctor's Response:

Dear Patient,

Thank you for sharing your wife's symptoms with me. Based on the information you have provided, I would like to offer the following advice:

1. Mild Light Discharge of Bleeding: If your wife's period is regular and the discharge is mild and light, it may not be a cause for concern. However, if the discharge is accompanied by any pain or discomfort, it is recommended to consult a gynecologist for further evaluation.

2. Sneezing: Sneezing can be caused by various reasons such as allergies, cold, or other respiratory conditions. If your wife's sneezing is severe and persistent, it is recommended to consult an ENT (Ear, Nose, and Throat) specialist to rule out any underlying conditions.

3. Antihistamines: If your wife is sensitive to allergic conditions and has been prescribed antihistamines by an ENT doctor, it is generally safe to take them under the guidance of a doctor. However, if she experiences any side effects or adverse reactions, she should immediately stop taking the medication and consult her doctor.

4. ChatDoctor Test: If your wife has not taken a ChatDoctor test, it may be a good idea to consider it. The test can help identify any underlying conditions and provide more accurate diagnosis.

In summary, I recommend that your wife consult a gynecologist and ENT specialist for further evaluation of her symptoms. If she experiences any discomfort or pain, she should seek immediate medical attention. Additionally, it is important for her to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep, which can help improve her overall health.
455:
As a doctor, I would like to know more about your condition. However, based on the information you have provided, here is my analysis:

Having a tooth pulled is a surgical procedure that can cause some degree of inflammation and infection. Fever, chills, and weakness in the legs can be symptoms of post-surgical infection or other systemic conditions.

It is important to monitor your temperature and other symptoms. If your temperature remains high, or if your symptoms worsen, you should contact your dentist or healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

Please take care of yourself and seek medical attention if necessary.
456:
Patient: Hi there, my husband had skin cancer which was removed in early September with skin taken from the neck and added to the head. He has also had an MRI scan of his head and neck and it was all clear! Just a few months later, he was saying he could feel a lump just above the scar in his neck and went for a follow-up and again everything was fine. But with pulling and pushing on this area, it seems to be getting bigger. Any advice apart from telling him to leave it alone? He is also suffering badly from hay-fever and wondered if this has anything to do with the lump?

Doctor: It is important to note that the lump your husband is feeling could be related to the surgery or another unrelated condition. However, we should not ignore it. I would recommend that your husband gets a follow-up appointment with his surgeon as soon as possible. They will be able to examine the lump and determine its nature.

If the surgeon determines that the lump is related to the surgery, they may recommend further testing or imaging to rule out any complications or recurrance of the skin cancer. If the lump is unrelated, the surgeon may recommend a referral to a general surgeon or a radiologist for further evaluation and management.

In terms of the hay-fever, it is unlikely to be related to the lump. However, it is important to manage hay-fever effectively to avoid any potential triggers that may worsen the condition. Your husband may need to discuss his symptoms with an allergist or ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) specialist to determine the best treatment options for him.

Please ensure that your husband follows the advice of his surgeon and takes any recommended tests or referrals seriously. I wish your husband a speedy recovery from his condition.
457:
Hello, patient. Based on the MRI scan of your spine, it shows several issues that we need to discuss.

1. Partial loss of lumbar lordosis: This means that the natural curvature of your lower back has partially flattened. Lordosis is the inward curvature of the spine that usually helps to support the upper body and distribute weight evenly.

2. Early degenerative changes of the spine in the form of marginal breaking: This indicates that your spine is undergoing early stages of degeneration, which is a natural process that occurs as we age. The marginal breaking is a result of this degeneration and can lead to bone spurs and other changes in the spine.

3. Irregularity of adjacent endplates at L4/L5 and L5/S1 vertebrate with partial dessication and partially reduced heights of L4-5 and L5-S1 disks: This suggests that there are changes in the endplates of your vertebrae, which are the bony structures that connect one vertebra to another. The dessication (dehydration) and partial reduction in disk height can lead to vertebral foraminal narrowing, which can compress nerves and cause pain.

4. Spinal canal narrowing at L4-5 level (10 mm) and severe at L5-S1 level (6.5 mm): This means that there is a narrowing of the spinal canal at the L4-5 level and an even more severe narrowing at the L5-S1 level. This can compress the nerves and lead to symptoms such as pain, numbness, or weakness in the legs or buttocks.

Based on these findings, it appears that you may be experiencing some degree of spinal stenosis, which is a narrowing of the spinal canal that can compress the nerves. This can lead to symptoms such as leg pain, numbness, or weakness. We need to conduct a thorough evaluation to determine the best course of treatment for you. It may involve conservative measures such as physical therapy, medications, and lifestyle changes to manage your symptoms. If conservative measures fail to provide relief, then surgical intervention may be considered. I will arrange for a follow-up appointment so we can discuss your options in detail and answer any further questions you may have.
458: Patient: Doctor has prescribed me Maxifol, but I am not sure whether to take this medicine or not. I am not pregnant yet, but I am afraid of gaining weight and have heard a lot about weight gain.
459:
Patient: Hi, my name is Rudy. I have had a very bad cough that has lasted over a month. I saw a doctor, but she said it was nothing just some dripping from the back of my nose. But now I am having coughing attacks to where it is forcing all the air out of my body. When I cough, I tend to burp or pass gas, and almost every time I cough, I begin to feel lightheaded and begin to have a migraine. And lately, it has been so bad that I have almost passed out due to lack of air. Please help. Thank you for your time.

Doctor: Thank you for your time, Rudy. It sounds like you are experiencing some serious symptoms. Based on your description, it seems like there may be some underlying conditions causing your symptoms. I recommend that you see a pulmonologist for a more detailed evaluation of your cough and potential causes. They will be able to perform additional tests and assess your condition more accurately. Please take care and get to the pulmonologist as soon as possible.
460:
As a doctor, I need to know more about your daughter's symptoms and health history to provide accurate answers and recommendations. However, based on the information you provided, your daughter may be experiencing some health issues that require further evaluation and treatment.

If your daughter's symptoms are affecting her daily life, it is important for her to consult a doctor as soon as possible for a comprehensive physical examination and evaluation. The doctor may recommend some tests, such as blood tests, urine tests, or imaging tests, to rule out any potential health conditions.

If your daughter's symptoms are caused by her adrenal glands, it is important for her to manage her stress levels and maintain a healthy lifestyle. She should also avoid stimulants and alcohol, which can further tax her adrenal glands. It is recommended that she consult a doctor who specializes in endocrinology or nephrology for further evaluation and treatment advice.

I hope your daughter's health issues can be resolved soon.
461:
Patient: I have a lump in my left nostril that I just noticed. I have been having trouble breathing out of my left nostril for quite some time now, and just noticed that there is something blocking it almost completely. I always thought this was allergies, until my right nostril cleared up and my left one never did. I am scared shitless.

Doctor: It is important to be evaluated by a doctor as soon as possible. The lump in your left nostril may be caused by various reasons, including but not limited to allergies, sinusitis, polyps, or even more serious conditions such as cancer. It is necessary to conduct a thorough examination and diagnostic testing to determine the cause of the lump and the appropriate treatment plan.

Do not worry too much, as the vast majority of lumps in the nasal cavity are not cancerous. However, it is still important to see a doctor promptly for evaluation and treatment to avoid any potential health risks.
462:
Patient: I've been feeling like something's going on, and I just recently had sex. I haven't had morning sickness for about 4 weeks now, but every time before I go to bed, I get a weird feeling in my stomach. I couldn't take a home pregnancy test or go to a doctor about it. What can I do, and how will I know if I'm pregnant or not?

Doctor: It's important to take a pregnancy test to confirm whether or not you're pregnant. If you can't get a home pregnancy test, you can try asking your local pharmacy or health center for help. They may be able to provide you with a test or refer you to a doctor who can perform a pregnancy test.

If the test is positive, it means that you are pregnant. However, if the test is negative, it doesn't mean that you're not pregnant, as the test may not be accurate if taken too early. If you're still concerned, you can wait a few days and take another test to confirm the result.

If you're pregnant, it's important to see a doctor as soon as possible for prenatal care. Pregnant women need regular check-ups to ensure the health of the fetus and to identify any potential problems.
463:
As a professional doctor, I can provide you with accurate answers to your medical questions.

First of all, congratulations on the birth of your baby boy! It is recommended that you and your husband wait for at least six weeks after delivery before engaging in sexual activity again. This is because the body needs time to recover from the physical and emotional changes of pregnancy and childbirth.

If you want to use a copper intrauterine device (IUD) as a form of contraception, the best time to insert it is usually after your postpartum check-up, which usually takes place six weeks after delivery. The doctor will need to ensure that your uterus has fully recovered and that there are no contraindications to using the IUD.

Copper IUDs are a safe and effective form of contraception that can be used by breastfeeding women. However, it is important to discuss all contraceptive options with your doctor to ensure that you choose the most suitable method for you and your family.

Finally, it is important to remember that sexual activity should be enjoyable and safe for both you and your partner. If you have any concerns or questions about your health or contraception options, please consult your doctor for professional advice.
466:
Patient: I have had positive HBsAg since 1995. I do my tests twice a year, which include ultrasound and LFT. Overall, they are normal. But my HBsAg test value is 5881, where the cut-off value is 1.00. This is very high. What does it indicate? Please keep in mind that HBeAg is currently negative.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your test results. Based on your HBsAg test value of 5881, it is indeed quite high. HBsAg is a marker for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, and a high level can indicate active infection or chronic hepatitis B. However, it's important to consider other factors such as liver function tests (LFTs) and ultrasound findings to assess the overall condition of your liver.

If your LFTs and ultrasound results are normal, it may indicate that your hepatitis B is stable and not causing significant damage to your liver at the moment. However, a high HBsAg level can also indicate a higher risk of developing cirrhosis or liver cancer in the future.

It's recommended to continue monitoring your condition regularly through blood tests and ultrasounds. If your condition remains stable, you may not require treatment at the moment. However, if your condition worsens or if your liver function starts to decline, you may need to consider antiviral treatment to reduce the risk of further liver damage.

Please consult a hepatologist (a liver specialist) for a more detailed evaluation and treatment advice specific to your situation. They will be able to provide you with a personalized management plan based on your test results and overall health status.
467:
Hello Mohana, I'm sorry to hear about your recurrent miscarriages. Miscarriage is a common occurrence, and it can be emotionally and physically challenging for both you and your family. However, it's important to seek medical attention to ensure the health of both you and your baby. Here are some possible reasons for recurrent miscarriages:

1. Genetic issues: Miscarriage can be caused by genetic issues in the fetus. If your doctor has already performed genetic testing and the results were normal, then this is unlikely to be the cause of your miscarriages.

2. Hormonal issues: Progesterone is a hormone that is essential for maintaining a pregnancy. If your progesterone levels are low, it can lead to a miscarriage. Your doctor may recommend monitoring your progesterone levels during your pregnancy to ensure they are adequate.

3. Infections: Infections such as urinary tract infections, vaginitis, or even common colds can affect a pregnancy and lead to miscarriage. It's important to notify your doctor if you have any symptoms of infection during pregnancy.

4. Lifestyle factors: Smoking, alcohol consumption, and drug use during pregnancy can increase the risk of miscarriage. It's essential to avoid these substances during pregnancy to ensure the health of your baby.

5. Uterine issues: Some women may have uterine issues that can affect their ability to maintain a pregnancy. If your doctor suspects any uterine issues, they may recommend additional tests such as ultrasounds or biopsies.

In your case, it's important to discuss your history of recurrent miscarriages with your doctor. They can review your medical history, conduct additional tests if necessary, and recommend treatment options such as changes in lifestyle, progesterone supplementation, or even consultations with a reproductive endocrinologist (RE) or infertility specialist if necessary. It's important to remain hopeful and seek medical attention to ensure the health of both you and your baby. I wish you the best in your journey and please take care of yourself emotionally and physically during this time.
468:
Patient: I am a 40-year-old female who had breast cancer in 2009. All treatments are now complete. For 10 weeks, I have had a constant stitch type pain in my left side under my rib cage. Some of my symptoms include black stools (only lasted 4 days), blood and mucus in my stools (lasted a week), stools now normal. I have nausea and feel full quickly. I have pain around the middle of my back. The pain in my side is worse after eating and when lying down. I have been to the doctor, and tested so far for ulcer and helicobacter, which are negative. Any ideas?

Doctor: It is important to rule out any potential causes of the pain, such as ulcers, helicobacter pylori infection, and other gastrointestinal conditions. If the tests for these conditions are negative, it is possible that the pain could be related to your breast cancer treatment or other non-gastrointestinal conditions. It is recommended to follow up with your doctor to ensure that all possible causes are ruled out. In the meantime, it may be helpful to avoid certain foods that could irritate your stomach, such as spicy or acidic foods, and to eat smaller meals more frequently. If the pain becomes severe or persistent, it is important to seek medical attention promptly.
469:
Patient: Hi, I was just told I have Acinetobater Lwoffii. I went in for a biopsy, it never started healing and a rash formed and itching really bad, went back into the dermotoligist office and they did a culture and it came back as MRSA. Started on Tetracycline right away for 14 days. Went in to my family doctor to get checked to have a all clear through a nose swab and another culture of the area, now this. I have requested another culture to be done before a start another series of antibiotics. I don't know what to do.

Doctor: It sounds like you've been through a lot with your health recently. Having a biopsy that doesn't heal and leading to a rash and itching can be very distressing. It's important to take your condition seriously and continue to work with your doctors to ensure proper treatment.

The fact that the culture from your biopsy came back positive for MRSA is concerning. MRSA is a type of staphylococcus bacteria that can be resistant to some antibiotics. However, the tetracycline you were prescribed is often effective against MRSA. It's important to complete the full course of antibiotics even if you feel better.

Before starting another series of antibiotics, it's a good idea to get another culture done to check if the infection has been fully eradicated. This will help guide your treatment plan going forward.

In the meantime, it's important to manage your symptoms and take care of yourself. Keep the infected area clean and dry, avoid scratching the rash as it can spread the infection, and rest well to support your immune system in fighting the infection.

If your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact your doctor for further guidance and support. They will be able to advise you on the best course of action moving forward.
472:
Patient: I constantly feel dizzy and tired and sometimes like I am going to pass out. I get enough sleep but I still feel exhausted. I have a history of low blood pressure and passing out but it also feels like my head is stuffy. I feel like there is something really wrong this has been going on for a few months now.

Doctor: It sounds like you are experiencing a variety of symptoms that could be related to several different conditions. Dizziness and fatigue can be caused by many things, including low blood pressure, anemia, or even anxiety or stress. And your symptoms have been going on for several months, which is concerning.

I would like to recommend some tests to rule out any physical conditions. We can start with a complete blood count to check for anemia, and then we can check your blood pressure and heart rate to make sure they are within a normal range. Additionally, we may need to conduct some further tests to rule out any underlying conditions that may be causing your symptoms.

In the meantime, it's important to manage your symptoms. I can recommend some lifestyle changes that may help, such as increasing your fluid intake, avoiding long periods of standing or sitting, and getting regular exercise. If your symptoms persist, please seek medical attention promptly.
473:
Patient: I went to the ER with complaints of pain in my right abdomen, nausea, and a blood pressure of 176/81. I was given fluids for dehydration, which also included cipro and pain medication. The doctor's diagnosis was kidney infection and I was prescribed 1000mg/day for 10 days. The problem is that I just finished a course of cipro (1000mg/day for 10 days) one week ago. Is it normal to have to take a second course of antibiotics?

Doctor: It is not uncommon to require a second course of antibiotics for certain infections, especially if the initial course was not sufficient to clear the infection. However, it is important to ensure that the second course is necessary and that the infection has not already been cleared. It is also important to ensure that the antibiotics prescribed are appropriate for the type of infection being treated.

In your case, if your doctor has diagnosed a kidney infection, then it is likely that a second course of antibiotics may be necessary to fully clear the infection. However, it is important to follow your doctor's advice and complete the course of antibiotics as prescribed. If you have any concerns or questions, it is recommended that you consult your doctor for further guidance.
475:
Patient: I have a bump on the right back side of the roof of my mouth. It is right next to the tooth that is farther back. It has pain when I brush my tongue over it. Also giving me a slight headache and earache. I just recently went to the dentist for a cleaning and they said my wisdom teeth were not even showing so what could this be?

Doctor: Based on your description, it seems like you might have an oral infection or a gum infection. The bump on the roof of your mouth could be a gum boil or a tonsillar infection. The pain when you brush your tongue over it is a common symptom of an oral infection. The headache and earache could be a result of the infection or maybe due to some allergies or sinus issues.

I recommend that you go back to the dentist and have them take a closer look at the bump. They can perform a thorough examination and determine the cause of the infection. If it is an oral infection, they may prescribe antibiotics to help clear it up. If it is a tonsillar infection, they may recommend throat medication or refer you to an ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) specialist for further evaluation.

In the meantime, you can try to relieve the symptoms by drinking plenty of fluids, using saltwater gargle, and taking over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen. If the symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention promptly.
476:
Patient,

You mentioned that you are feeling tired, sweating on your face, experiencing nausea and stomach pain. It is important to note that these are potential side effects of the medication you are taking, Olmetec. Please consult your doctor immediately to report these side effects and discuss further management options.

In the meantime, it is essential to continue monitoring your blood pressure. Please ensure that you measure your blood pressure at home regularly and keep track of the readings. If your blood pressure remains high or if the side effects persist, your doctor may need to adjust your medication or recommend additional treatment options.

Furthermore, you mentioned that you have been going to the gym for three months but have not lost weight. Although exercise is an important component of any weight loss program, it may not be sufficient in isolation. It is essential to combine a healthy diet with regular exercise to achieve optimal results. Speak to your doctor or a nutritionist to develop an appropriate diet plan that suits your body type, lifestyle and medical condition.

Lastly, it is essential to get a good night's sleep. Ensure that you maintain a regular sleep schedule and aim for 7-8 hours of sleep every night. Lack of sleep can contribute to fatigue and other symptoms.

Please consult your doctor immediately to discuss these issues further and receive appropriate guidance.
477:
Patient: I keep getting a cramp in the left side of my tongue. It only happened when I was asleep, so I thought I might be biting it, but now it's happening when I'm awake too. It's very painful. What can I do? Also, there is like a bump on my tongue where it cramps at.

Doctor: It sounds like you're experiencing a tongue cramp, which can be caused by various reasons. One possible cause is biting or pressure on the tongue while sleeping, which can lead to a muscle strain. Another possibility is a small muscle spasm due to anxiety or stress.

To relieve the pain, you can try applying pressure to the cramped area with your fingers or by sucking on a cold object, such as an ice cube or a cold tablet. You can also try massaging the area gently with your fingers or taking a warm saltwater mouthwash to soothe the irritated tissue.

If the pain persists or if you're experiencing any other symptoms, such as difficulty speaking or swallowing, I recommend seeing a dentist for a more thorough examination. The dentist may recommend additional treatment options, such as Botox injections or splints, to relieve the cramping and relieve your symptoms.

Please note that this advice is general and may not apply to everyone. It's important to consult a professional healthcare provider for a accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.
479:
Patient: Sometimes, especially when I do an intense workout or lifting, there are about 6-7 lumps in my forearm. They are soft lumps and each one is about half an inch apart. If I stop and rest, it goes away, or if I put my hands over my head, it stops. Is this bad and what is it?

Doctor: Based on your description, it seems like you might be experiencing some form of muscle or tendon injury or strain. The lumps could be a result of muscle fibroses or a formation of scar tissue due to the injury. It is recommended that you stop any strenuous activity that could further damage the area and seek medical attention for a proper diagnosis and treatment advice. It is important to get a proper diagnosis to rule out any other possible conditions that could be causing the lumps.
480:
Patient: Hi, I have H.O.C and am taking metoprolol and atorvastatin. My blood pressure is regularly around 120/80. Yesterday I ate a steak for lunch and baked pork and saurkrout for dinner. Last night I couldn't sleep and my chest got tight around 1 am. Is this because of what I ate yesterday?

Doctor: Hello, based on your description, the symptoms you experienced last night may be related to the food you ate yesterday. Eating a large amount of red meat and high-fat food can lead to indigestion, chest tightness and other symptoms. However, it is also possible to be caused by other factors, such as anxiety, hyperventilation, etc. It is recommended that you go to the hospital for a comprehensive examination and evaluation to exclude other possible causes. At the same time, you should also maintain good habits and healthy lifestyles to prevent similar symptoms from occurring again in the future.
481:
Hello Patient,

I understand your situation is complex and emotional. IVF has been attempted twice without success, and you are considering other options for your wife and sister-in-law. Your wife had a tubectomy in 2007, and you are 41 years old.

In general, the procedure for reversing a tubectomy is called a tubal reversal or tubal reanastomosis. This procedure involves reconnecting the fallopian tubes, allowing for fertilization and pregnancy to occur. The success rate of tubal reversals depends on many factors, including the type of tubectomy performed, the condition of the fallopian tubes after surgery, the age of the woman, and her overall health.

For your wife, since she had a tubectomy in 2007, it is important to know the type of tubectomy she had and the condition of her fallopian tubes after the surgery. If her tubes were removed completely, then tubal reversal may not be possible. If her tubes were partially removed or she had a laparoscopic tubal ligation, then reversal may be possible but the success rate will still be affected by her age and other factors.

For your sister-in-law, if she has a healthy reproductive system and age is not a factor, she may be a candidate for IVF again or other fertility treatments.

It is recommended that you seek consultations with fertility specialists who can evaluate your wife and sister-in-law's specific situations and provide detailed information about the procedures, risks, and success rates. In addition, it is important to consider the emotional impact of this process on all parties involved.

Please make an appointment with a fertility specialist in London who can provide you with more specific information and guidance based on your wife's and sister-in-law's individual circumstances.
482:
Patient: Hello. My 10-year-old son is passing gas more than usual. He has a fairly good diet and is generally healthy. It's starting to cause him a bit of trouble at school and with his music lessons, but he says he isn't nervous. Now it's starting to worry him. I know it's common to let a few go, but this is more than average. Thank you.

Doctor: Hello, thank you for bringing your son's issue to my attention. Passing gas is a common occurrence, and most people do not require any treatment for it. However, if your son's farting is causing him distress or affecting his daily activities, we may need to explore some options. Could you please tell me more about his symptoms? How long has this been happening? Any other symptoms?
483:
Patient: Good morning, doctor. Last night my husband was bitten by a pet dog. After that, he washed with running tap water and soap. He took a tetanus shot. Is it enough or is there any further treatment to take? And should he avoid jogging and ground nuts? Please give your valuable solution. Thank you.

Doctor: Hello, the treatment for a dog bite injury depends on the severity of the bite. If the bite is minor, washing with soap and water and getting a tetanus shot may be sufficient. However, if the bite is deep or involves a large area, you may need to consider additional treatments such as antibiotics or rabies vaccination, depending on the situation.

As for avoiding jogging and ground nuts, there is no specific recommendation. However, it is generally recommended to avoid strenuous exercise and foods that may cause allergies or adverse reactions until the injury has fully recovered.

It is important to monitor your husband's condition closely and seek medical attention if there are any signs of infection or other complications. Additionally, it is recommended to contact the dog's owner to ensure that the dog is rabies vaccinated and to consider seeking legal advice if necessary.

Please note that this advice is general and may not apply to all cases. It is important to seek medical attention promptly and follow the advice of a healthcare professional.
484:
Patient: Hi, I have a lump above my belly button on the left hand side. It hurts when pressed. My whole stomach and tummy area have been sore for a few weeks now. Anything I eat hurts my stomach, and I cannot hold food. This pain is a 9/10. It seems to be getting worse. Do you know what it could be?

Doctor: Based on your description, it seems like you might have a condition called "acute abdomen." This is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention. The lump you're feeling could be a sign of a ruptured appendix or another abdominal organ problem.

I recommend that you go to the nearest hospital immediately for a thorough examination and treatment. If your pain is a 9/10, it's very important to seek medical attention as soon as possible.

Please don't hesitate to go to the hospital. I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing such pain, and I hope that you'll recover soon.
486:
Patient: My father is 67 years old. Last month, he was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. Dr started the medicine myestin 60, one tab three times a day. My father has 10% relief. Now dr suggest to start a new medicine azoran 50 g. But this have some side effects. Blood test report is ACHR ANTIBODIES, ACETYL CHOLINE RECEPTOR ANTIBODIES 20.1. Nmol/l please suggest me. What can I do???

Doctor: Hello, your father has been diagnosed with myasthenia gravis and is currently taking medication for it. The doctor has recommended starting a new medication, azoran 50 g, but it has some side effects. Based on the blood test report, the ACHR antibodies and acetylcholine receptor antibodies levels are elevated at 20.1 nM/L.

My suggestion is to discuss with the doctor the potential side effects of the azoran medication and explore other treatment options for your father. It's important to manage myasthenia gravis effectively to improve his symptoms and quality of life. The doctor can review the blood test results and other relevant information to guide you through this process. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to discuss them with the doctor.
488:
Hello Meagan,

Thank you for sharing your health concerns with me. It sounds like you have been experiencing irregular periods and a variety of symptoms that could potentially impact your fertility.

Firstly, missing a period and having a two-month late cycle is irregular and could indicate a hormonal imbalance or other health issues. The flow of your periods also seems variable, which could suggest a problem with the consistency of your uterine lining.

The blood clots and severe period pain you described could be signs of uterine fibroids, a condition that can cause irregular periods, heavy bleeding, and lower back pain. Fibroids are benign growths in the uterus that can interfere with fertility.

To address your concerns, I recommend a comprehensive evaluation by a gynecologist. This evaluation should include a pelvic exam, Pap smear, and ultrasound to assess the condition of your uterus and ovaries. These tests can help identify any structural abnormalities or potential causes of infertility.

If the evaluation reveals fibroids, your gynecologist can recommend treatment options such as medication, surgery, or a combination of both. Medications such as gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (GnRH agonists) can help shrink fibroids and improve symptoms. Surgical options may include fibroid removal or uterine artery embolization.

In addition to fibroids, other potential causes of infertility include ovulatory disorders, tubal issues, and male factor infertility. It is important to rule out these conditions through appropriate testing.

I understand your desire to become pregnant and the emotional toll it can take. Infertility is a common problem affecting many couples, and there are numerous treatment options available.

Please follow up with your doctor promptly to arrange for a comprehensive evaluation. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to consult me. I wish you the best in your journey to conceive a child.
489:
As a doctor, I recommend that you contact your doctor as soon as possible to discuss your symptoms and medication usage. They will be able to provide you with specific guidance on whether to take the correct dose of Methtrexate or to wait for further evaluation.

It is important to take Methtrexate exactly as prescribed, as it can have serious side effects if taken in incorrect doses. Your doctor will be able to advise you on the best course of action based on your symptoms and overall health.

If you experience any concerning symptoms or side effects, it is essential to contact your doctor promptly for evaluation and guidance. They will be able to provide you with the appropriate care and advice based on your specific situation.
490: Patient: Two days before my pet bit me, I went to the government hospital where they gave me a tetanus injection, IDRV injection, and they told me to take equiralo injection. But there was a reaction for equiralo. They advised me for HRIG VACCINE but I didn't take it. Is there any problem with this? My dog is vaccinated one year back. The bite was an provoked bite.
491: Hello, I am a professional doctor. According to your description, the difference in appearance of veins on both arms is common. It may be due to individual differences in the anatomical structure of the arms or the different levels of exercise and physical activities on both sides. If you are still worried about this, you can go to the hospital for a comprehensive examination and diagnosis by a doctor.
492:
Patient: I have an elevated platelet count of 542... my mother was recently diagnosed with multiple myeloma and is now in remission and my younger sister was diagnosed with RA at age 40. I am a diabetic also. Should I be concerned? Physician says I need to see a Hematologist but I don't want to look for trouble. Is my level high enough to warrant having testing and if so, what should I be looking for? Also, TSH is now elevated at 4.462. This was normal 6 months ago.

Doctor: Your platelet count of 542 is indeed elevated, which can increase the risk of blood clots and thrombotic events. Given your family history of multiple myeloma, RA, and diabetes, it is important to consider the possibility of a genetic predisposition towards elevated platelet counts. However, not all elevated platelet counts indicate a serious condition.

It is recommended that you see a hematologist for further evaluation and testing to determine the cause of your elevated platelet count. The hematologist may recommend additional blood tests, bone marrow aspiration, or genetic testing to rule out any potential underlying conditions.

With regard to your TSH level of 4.462, this is indeed elevated. TSH is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland that regulates the production of thyroid hormones. Elevated TSH levels can indicate an underactive thyroid gland, which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and changes in bowel and heart rate. It is recommended that you discuss this finding with your primary care provider or endocrinologist for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.

It is important to be proactive about your health and to seek medical attention when necessary. While it is possible to have elevated platelet counts and an underactive thyroid gland without any serious conditions, it is important to rule out any potential underlying conditions to ensure your health and well-being.
493:
Patient: I fell on my and jerked my hip very bad. It is very sore while walking or taking steps. I had an xray done that showed normal and I am on anti-flammatory medicine but I am still in a lot of pain. Do you have any ideas of what is wrong? My Doctor is not very helpful.

Doctor: It sounds like you have injured your hip joint. X-rays may not always detect soft tissue injuries, so it's possible that you have a strain or tear in the ligaments or muscles surrounding your hip. I would recommend a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan to better visualize the soft tissues in your hip region. This will help to identify any tears or damage to the ligaments and muscles.

In the meantime, it's important to continue taking the anti-inflammatory medication as it can help to reduce the inflammation and swelling in the injured area. You should also avoid putting weight on the injured hip as much as possible to give it time to heal. Ice packs can also be applied to the area to relieve any pain and swelling.

If your pain persists or if your symptoms worsen, it's important to seek further medical attention. Consider seeing a different doctor or seeking a second opinion to ensure that your injury is being properly diagnosed and treated.
496:
Patient: I'm having a hard time taking a deep breath. I have no cough or wheezing. When I am able to take a deep breath, my upper right back and shoulder hurt. My neck is sore in the back as well, it just feels like my head is really heavy. Any ideas what could be wrong?

Doctor: It sounds like you might be experiencing some chest tightness or discomfort, which can be caused by a variety of reasons. One possibility is that you might have a condition called costochondritis, which is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone. This can cause pain and tenderness in the chest and shoulder area.

Another possibility is that you might have a problem with your lungs or respiratory system, such as a collapsed lung or pleurisy, an inflammation of the pleura, the membrane that surrounds the lungs. This can also cause chest tightness and discomfort, as well as shortness of breath.

It's important to see a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention promptly.

Patient: Several weeks ago, I treated myself with over the counter meds for what I thought was a nasty yeast infection. Then, the following week, my husband complained of itching and a red rash in and on his genitals, but he didn't do/take anything and it went away. Now, I have what I think is a yeast infection again. Could we be passing a yeast infection or something else back and forth? What can I do to make this go away? I have endometriosis. Am I more likely to just get lots of yeast infections?

Doctor: It is possible that you and your husband could be passing a yeast infection back and forth, especially if you have been sexual with each other recently. Yeast infections are common and can be transmitted during sexual contact. However, it is also possible that you are both experiencing individual infections.

To make the yeast infection go away, it is recommended to take the appropriate treatment for the infection. If your doctor has prescribed medication for your yeast infection, take it as directed. If you are experiencing symptoms of a yeast infection, such as itching, redness, and discharge, avoid using scented soaps, douches, and feminine hygiene products as these can irritate the vagina and cause symptoms to worsen.

Endometriosis can increase your risk of yeast infections. Endometriosis is a condition where the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus grows outside of the uterus, often on the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and other pelvic structures. This tissue can become infected and cause pain and other symptoms. If you have endometriosis, it is important to manage it through treatment and lifestyle changes, such as maintaining a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, and reducing stress.

If your symptoms persist or worsen, it is important to contact your doctor for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.

Last year in October, I had about 4 weeks of heavy bleeding. I had an ultrasound and it was discovered that I had cysts on my ovaries. Since getting the bleeding to stop last October, I have been taking a lot of vitamins - folic acid and B complex especially - and also a heavy dose of herbal medications. 

What concerns me now is that I haven't had a period since then. Yes, I have had unprotected sex since that October, in fact that November. It's been many months now and I want to know what are my chances of being pregnant. I did one of those online pregnancy calculators and when asked to fill in my last period, I did which was October 26, 2012 and it told me the day I might have conceived which was the exact date I had intercourse. 

Now I am experiencing nausea, indigestion, mood swings, weight gain, a lot of sleeping and always tired, breast tenderness at times. What confuses me is that when I researched PCOS, I read that it mimics pregnancy symptoms and I took a home pregnancy test (HPT) which had a negative result but I know my body and I have never missed a period for this long. 

Could I be pregnant?

Thank you for providing all this information. Based on your description, it seems like you may have polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can cause irregular periods and symptoms like the ones you are experiencing. However, it's also possible that you could be pregnant, despite the negative HPT result. 

It's important to get a blood test to confirm your pregnancy status. If the blood test is negative, then we can proceed with testing and treatment for PCOS. In the meantime, it's important to continue to take care of yourself by eating a balanced diet, getting enough exercise, and reducing stress levels. 

If your symptoms worsen or if your period still hasn't arrived after a few weeks, please come back to see me. We can then proceed with further testing and treatment options.

514:
It is concerning that your father is experiencing memory loss, trouble speaking, trouble operating simple tasks, and seems to be increasingly agitated. These symptoms could be caused by a number of conditions, including but not limited to:

1. Mild cognitive impairment (MCI): MCI is a condition where individuals have some memory loss and cognitive difficulties that are more severe than normal aging but not as severe as dementia.
2. Dementia: Dementia is a severe loss of cognitive function that affects daily life. It can include memory loss, confusion, agitation, and other symptoms.
3. Stroke: A stroke can cause sudden memory loss, confusion, and other cognitive symptoms.
4. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease can cause motor symptoms (such as tremors and slowed movement) as well as cognitive symptoms (such as memory loss and confusion).

It is important to see a neurologist to evaluate your father's symptoms and determine the cause of his cognitive decline. A neurologist is a doctor who specializes in the diagnosis and treatment of conditions that affect the brain and nervous system. They will perform a physical exam and may order some tests, such as a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan or a blood test, to help determine the cause of your father's symptoms.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to provide your father with a structured daily routine, reduce his stress levels, and provide him with activities that stimulate his mind. Additionally, it may be beneficial to have someone around who can assist him with daily tasks, such as driving or operating appliances.

Patient: hi Doctor, I have three questions for you, my first: I am 27 with diagnosed osteoporosis. I have recently been passing blood in my stool as well as have been in severe back pain with occasional abdominal pain, nauesa and faintness - would you know what could be causing the blood in my stool? I am not constipated, dont smoke or drink and live a healthy lifestyle. Second: My recent scan said that I have a generalised annual laxity of the L4/5 and L3/4 vertebrae. What is an annual laxity? My scan also mentions degenerative changes in the L3/4. Third: What could I do to build the density of my bones? Thank you for your time.

Doctor: Hello, I am a doctor. Let me answer your three questions. First, regarding your stool blood, it could be caused by various reasons such as colonoscopy, ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, or even colon cancer. However, given your age and lifestyle habits, the likelihood of colon cancer is relatively low. It is recommended that you undergo a colonoscopy examination to determine the cause of the blood in your stool.

Second, the term "annual laxity" refers to the degree of flexibility or looseness of the vertebrae in the spine. Generalised annual laxity means that there is an overall increase in the flexibility of the vertebrae in the spine. Degenerative changes in the vertebrae often occur with ageing and can be caused by various factors such as genetics, diet, lack of exercise, and other lifestyle habits. If your scan shows degenerative changes in the L3/4 vertebrae, it means that there is some damage or changes in that area of your spine.

Third, to build bone density, you can consider lifestyle changes such as increasing weight-bearing exercise, reducing caffeine and alcohol intake, and maintaining a balanced diet rich in calcium and vitamin D. In addition, you can also consider taking bone-building drugs such as bisphosphonates or denosumab to help increase bone density. However, it is recommended that you consult a doctor for further evaluation and treatment advice.

I hope my answers have helped you. If you have any other questions or concerns, please feel free to ask me.

My doctor today prescribed wysolone 10mg for 10 days (3/day for first 5 days and then 2/day). I just read about the drug thats its a steroid and has several side effects... now should I take the drug or not. Also, ever since this allergy developed, I'm taking levocet 5mg every night...

Doctor: Firstly, I would like to know more about your skin allergy. Have you been diagnosed with any specific allergy or condition? The wysolone (prednisolone) your doctor prescribed is a corticosteroid that can help reduce the inflammation and itching associated with your skin allergy. However, as with any medication, there are side effects that can occur.

The side effects of wysolone can include:

- Mood changes
- Weight gain
- Increased risk of infections
- High blood sugar levels
- Muscle weakness
- Easy bruising
- Stomach upset
- Loss of bone density

If you are concerned about the side effects, it is important to discuss your concerns with your doctor. They can advise you on the risks and benefits of taking the medication, and may recommend alternative treatment options if necessary.

In addition, you mentioned that you are currently taking levocetirizine (Levocet 5mg). This is an antihistamine that can also help relieve the symptoms of your skin allergy. It is important to continue taking this medication as prescribed by your doctor, and do not stop taking it suddenly as this can lead to rebound symptoms.

If you have any further questions or concerns, it is important to discuss them with your doctor. They can provide you with more information and guidance on the best treatment options for your skin allergy.

539:
Patient: My 11-year-old son is complaining of pain in his testicles. It's not bad enough that he can't play outside, but I can tell he is uncomfortable. He has an appointment with his doctor, but she couldn't see him until Wednesday. He is a nervous wreck and I am a single mom. I am hoping you can explain to us what will happen during the exam.

Doctor: When your son has an appointment for a testicular exam, the doctor will perform a physical examination to evaluate his testicles for any signs of injury or infection. The doctor may also ask him some questions about the pain he is experiencing, such as the location, duration, and frequency of the pain.

During the physical examination, the doctor will palpate the testicles to check for any tenderness or lumps. They may also perform a test called a cremasteric reflex, where they tap the skin above the testicle and observe its reaction. This can help to determine if there is any underlying problem with the nerves or muscles in the area.

If the doctor suspects an infection, they may recommend a urinalysis to check for any signs of a urinary tract infection. If there are any concerns about the possibility of a more serious condition, such as a tumor or hernia, the doctor may recommend additional tests, such as a blood test or ultrasound.

It's important to note that testicular pain can have a variety of causes, including injury, infection, and other less serious conditions. However, it's also important to seek medical attention promptly if your son is experiencing persistent or severe pain, as some conditions may require prompt treatment to prevent long-term effects on his health.

544:
Patient: I have an acoustic neuroma. It was found in 2002. I had the lazer treatment at the Chicago Institute of Neurology. They said it came on quickly, and I had to watch it. I haven't had any problems since this year. I am in perfect health. I am 49, 127 pounds, workout, college graduate. I fell in July. I don't remember anything about the fall, except that there was blood all over the floor. I spent 4 days and had a cardiologist and neurologist follow up. Since the fall, I cannot look up or down without getting dizzy. The neurologist gave me meclizine. What is your opinion?

Doctor's Response:

Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that grows on the vestibular nerve, which is responsible for balance and hearing. It can cause symptoms such as hearing loss, dizziness, and balance problems.

Laser treatment is a method used to treat acoustic neuromas, but it is not always effective. If your tumor has not responded to laser treatment, it may require other treatment options such as microsurgery or radiation therapy.

Based on your description, your fall may have been caused by a vestibular event related to your acoustic neuroma. The neurologist's diagnosis and treatment with meclizine is reasonable given your symptoms of dizziness. However, it is important to continue to monitor your condition closely and follow up with your neurologist regularly to ensure that your symptoms are improving.

If your symptoms do not improve with meclizine or if they worsen, you should contact your neurologist immediately. Additional testing may be necessary to evaluate your condition and determine if other treatment options are necessary.
545:
Based on your description, it seems like you may have had some form of neurological event or issue during your pregnancy that has left you with some persistent symptoms. The symptoms you are experiencing now could be related to that event or could be something else entirely. Here are some things you can consider and discuss with your doctor:

1. Repeat Testing: It sounds like you have already had some testing done, but it might be worthwhile to repeat some of these tests to see if there have been any changes. This could include blood tests, ECGs, and nerve conduction studies.

2. Imaging Studies: If your symptoms are consistent with a neurological condition, imaging studies such as a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of your brain or a computed tomography (CT) scan of your chest/abdomen might be helpful.

3. Cardiology Follow-Up: Since you mentioned your heart rate is irregular, it might be worthwhile to see a cardiologist for a follow-up. They can assess your heart condition and recommend any necessary tests or procedures.

4. Genetic Testing: Given your family history of diabetes, it might be beneficial to consider genetic testing to see if there are any markers for diabetes or other conditions in your family.

5. Anxiety Management: It's important to remember that anxiety can often exacerbate symptoms and make them feel more severe. It might be helpful to consider anxiety management techniques such as relaxation exercises, mindfulness, or cognitive behavioral therapy.

6. Diet and Lifestyle Changes: If your symptoms are consistent with diabetes or pre-diabetes, changes to your diet and lifestyle can help manage the condition. This might include a balanced diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep.

It's important to remember that it's always best to consult a professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They can assess your symptoms, recommend any necessary tests or procedures, and provide you with the best treatment options available.
547:

If these measures are unsuccessful or if the lump is found to be caused by another condition, further treatment options may be recommended.

Remember, this is just a possible diagnosis based on your description. It's important to be evaluated by a healthcare provider to get a accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment recommendations.

Hello patient,

I am sorry to hear about your miscarriage and the issues you are facing with your periods. As a doctor, I would like to provide you with some information and guidance on your situation.

Firstly, it is important to understand that miscarriage can have an impact on your hormone levels and your menstrual cycle. It may take some time for your body to regulate and establish a regular pattern again. Therefore, it is not uncommon to experience irregular periods after a miscarriage.

In your case, it has been 3 months since your miscarriage and you are trying to conceive again. If your periods are irregular, it can make it difficult to predict when you may be ovulating and fertile. However, there is no need to clean your uterus in this situation. Cleansing the uterus is not a routine procedure and is usually only considered in specific cases such as severe uterine infection or heavy bleeding.

Instead, I recommend that you continue to monitor your periods and try to establish a pattern. You can use ovulation kits or basal body temperature charts to help identify when you are ovulating. This information can assist you in timing intercourse to increase the chances of conception.

If your periods remain irregular or if you have any concerns about your fertility, it is important to consult a fertility specialist for further evaluation and guidance. They can perform tests to assess your hormone levels, ovulation, and uterine health, and provide personalized recommendations for your situation.

Please take care and I wish you the best in your efforts to conceive again. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to seek professional advice.
