553:
Patient: I had a laparoscopy and afterwards a hard lump appeared under my belly button, so they prescribed me metronidazole. The doctor told me it was caused by bruising and that it's a big ball of blood. How long until this goes away? Are the doctors just lying to me?

Doctor: After a laparoscopy, it is possible to experience some post-surgical changes that can vary from person to person. A hard lump under the belly button could indeed be due to bruising or collection of blood, which is a common occurrence following such procedures. The prescribed metronidazole may be a prophylactic measure to prevent any infection that may arise from the surgery site.

The healing process following laparoscopy can vary depending on the individual's response and the complexity of the surgery. The lump under the belly button might take a few weeks to disappear, but it could also take longer in some cases. It is important to allow the body time to heal and for the bruising and blood collections to resolve naturally.

It is important to remember that doctors do not lie to their patients. They are trained to provide accurate and honest information based on their professional knowledge and experience. If you have any concerns or doubts, it is always best to discuss them with your doctor to ensure a clear understanding of your condition and the expected course of recovery.
555:
Patient: I have a liquid-filled swelling at the base of my right hand, just above the wrist. It was broken four months ago and repaired with a metal plate and screws. I seem to be losing movement - is it tendon overuse or infection? How can I tell the difference?

Doctor: It is important to distinguish between tendon overuse and infection in cases like yours. Here are some ways to tell the difference:

1. Symptoms: Tendon overuse often causes pain and stiffness, especially when using the hand. Infection, on the other hand, often causes redness, warmth, and swelling around the affected area.

2. Duration: Tendon overuse symptoms usually improve with rest and NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs). If the symptoms last longer than a few days or worsen, it could be an infection.

3. Swelling: If the swelling is soft and fluid-filled, it could be a tendon sheath infection or ganglion cyst. If the swelling is firm and tender, it could be an infection or a hematoma (collection of blood).

4. Movement: Loss of movement can be caused by tendon overuse, but if there is severe pain or swelling, it could be an infection.

5. Temperature: If the area feels warm to the touch, it could be an infection.

6. Surgical Site: If you have had recent surgery, it is important to consider infection as a possibility. However, tendon overuse is also common after surgery.

If you have concerns about your symptoms, it is recommended to consult a hand surgeon for a thorough examination and diagnosis. They can determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment recommendations.

Patient's husband has been recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. He had Gleason score of 9, 45% of his biopsies were cancerous, and his PSA level was 18. He is scheduled for a prostatectomy in the first week of June and is currently receiving hormone therapy. He has been experiencing symptoms of fatigue, achiness, and flu-like symptoms. One of his legs is swollen, and tonight he has a low-grade fever. The patient is concerned that these symptoms may indicate cancer spread or a reaction to the hormone therapy. The patient notes that her husband is otherwise in good shape, exercises regularly, and eats healthily. The couple was surprised by the diagnosis.

Answer:

It is possible that the symptoms your husband is experiencing could be related to the cancer itself or to the hormone therapy he is receiving. However, it is also possible that these symptoms could be unrelated to his cancer diagnosis.

The Gleason score of 9 and the presence of a high percentage of cancerous biopsies indicate a more aggressive form of prostate cancer. Spread of the cancer to other parts of the body is a possibility, and this could explain the symptoms he is experiencing. However, these symptoms could also be caused by the hormone therapy, which can lead to fatigue, aches and pains, and changes in body composition.

The low-grade fever could be a result of several different things, including infection, reaction to the hormone therapy, or spread of the cancer. It is important to monitor his temperature and other symptoms, such as cough, shortness of breath, or changes in bowel movements, and seek medical attention if these symptoms worsen or persist.

During the period leading up to the prostatectomy and after the surgery, it is important to remain in close communication with your husband's medical team. They will be able to provide more specific information about his diagnosis and treatment options. It is also important to remind your husband to continue with his healthy lifestyle practices, including regular exercise and a balanced diet, as this can help him maintain his strength and overall health during this challenging time.

562:
Hello, I am a doctor. Based on your hormone levels, high prolactin and low FSH can indeed affect your fertility. However, the primary cause of infertility is usually a physical problem such as blockage of the fallopian tubes, ovulation issues, or other reproductive system issues. Prolactin is a hormone that is produced by the pituitary gland and is responsible for milk production in women. High prolactin levels can suppress ovulation and cause infertility. FSH is a hormone that is produced by the pituitary gland and is responsible for stimulating follicle development and ovulation. A low FSH level can indicate a problem with follicle development or ovulation.

Balancing hormones to improve fertility is a complex process that requires individualized treatment plans. It is important to consult with a fertility specialist or endocrinologist who can evaluate your specific situation and recommend appropriate treatment options.

Diet can play a role in balancing hormones, but it is not a substitute for medical treatment. A balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats can support overall health and well-being. However, it is important to consult with a doctor or registered dietitian who can create a personalized eating plan for you based on your specific health needs and goals.

In addition to diet, lifestyle changes such as reducing stress, engaging in regular exercise, and avoiding alcohol and caffeine can also help balance hormones and improve fertility. It is important to manage stress levels through relaxation techniques, mindfulness practices, or seeking support from a mental health professional if necessary. Regular exercise can help improve overall health and well-being but should be done gradually and safely under the guidance of a healthcare professional. Avoiding alcohol and caffeine may help reduce the negative impact on fertility but should be done in consultation with a doctor or healthcare professional.

If you are experiencing infertility issues, it is important to consult with a fertility specialist or endocrinologist who can evaluate your specific situation and recommend appropriate treatment options for balancing hormones and improving fertility.

As a doctor, I cannot provide a direct answer to whether your mother is in the final stages of heart failure without more information. However, based on the information you have provided, it does seem like your mother may be experiencing some form of fluid retention, which can be a sign of heart failure.

Heart failure occurs when the heart is unable to pump blood efficiently, resulting in fluid buildup in the lungs, ankles, or abdomen. If your mother's fluid retention is caused by heart failure, she may experience shortness of breath, ankle swelling, or abdominal bloating.

If your mother's condition is indeed caused by heart failure, the final stages can vary depending on the severity of the condition and her overall health. In some cases, heart failure can progress to the point where the heart is unable to pump blood effectively and the patient may require specialized care such as hospice or palliative care.

However, it's important to note that fluid retention can also be caused by other conditions such as kidney disease, liver disease, or even certain medications. Therefore, it's crucial to consult a doctor for a comprehensive evaluation and diagnosis.

In the meantime, you can help manage your mother's symptoms by ensuring she avoids salt-rich foods, stays hydrated, and avoids activities that may strain her heart. It's also important to monitor her symptoms and seek medical attention promptly if her condition worsens.

575:
Patient: Hi, I would like to ask about my husband's ALP increasing. He has a fatty liver and high cholesterol, HDL - 38, LDL - 139, Triglyceride - 242, and ALP in 2009 - Oct. - 355, 2010 Oct - 383 and 2011 Feb - 404. Can you tell me if there is any specific reason for this or anything causing this problem? He is undergoing Abdominal echo test on 24th Feb 2011. but I am worried and would like to know some tips about it.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your concerns. The ALP (alkaline phosphatase) enzyme is a liver enzyme that is often measured to assess liver health. The increasing ALP levels in your husband's blood may indicate liver damage or a liver disease. However, the causes of increased ALP levels can vary and may not always be related to liver disease. Other possible reasons include:

1. Age: As we age, the liver enzyme levels may naturally increase.

2. Obesity: Excess body fat can lead to fatty liver disease and may be linked to increased ALP levels.

3. Consumption of alcohol: Long-term heavy alcohol consumption can damage the liver and result in elevated ALP levels.

4. Medications: Some medications may affect liver function and cause an increase in ALP levels.

5. Infections: Infections such as hepatitis can damage the liver and lead to elevated ALP levels.

6. Genetic factors: Some people may have a genetic predisposition to elevated ALP levels.

It is important to note that elevated ALP levels alone do not necessarily indicate a serious condition. However, it should be followed closely and your husband's doctor may recommend additional tests such as a liver biopsy to assess the extent of liver damage and rule out any underlying conditions. In the meantime, it is important for your husband to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoidance of alcohol and any hepatotoxic medications. I hope this information helps you understand the potential causes of elevated ALP levels and what steps can be taken to manage it effectively. Please discuss these concerns with your husband's doctor for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.
578:
Patient: I have acne on my face. Sometimes my face is clean, then it bursts out. What can I use to balance these acne to make my face smooth? I have tried ClearActive, ProActive, and Clearsil. I've tried many other things, but it's still the same.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your experience. Acne is a common skin condition that can be difficult to manage. To balance your acne and make your face smooth, I recommend a combination of approaches.

Firstly, it's important to maintain a consistent skin care routine. Use a gentle cleanser to remove makeup and dirt from your face. Avoid using products that contain comedogenic ingredients, as they can clog pores and worsen acne.

Secondly, consider using a topical treatment such as benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid. These products help to unclog pores, reduce inflammation, and shrink the size of acne lesions. However, it's essential to use these products only as directed and to introduce them gradually to minimize any potential side effects.

If your acne is severe or persistent, it may be necessary to consult a dermatologist for a professional evaluation and treatment recommendations. They may recommend oral antibiotics or other systemic treatments to address the underlying causes of your acne.

Remember that every person's skin is different, and what works for one person may not work for another. It may take some time to find the right combination of products and approaches that work for your skin.
579: As a professional doctor, I cannot provide you with medical advice directly. However, if you are currently taking medication, it is important to follow your doctor's advice and take the medication regularly. Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on the information you provided, you have had jaundice twice in the past and now again you are suffering from jaundice. Your current doctor has kept your case under observation. You also mentioned that you are currently experiencing nausea, which makes you feel very uncomfortable.

Jaundice refers to the yellowing of the skin and eyes caused by elevated bilirubin levels in the blood. The elevated bilirubin levels can be caused by various reasons such as Gilbert's syndrome, hepatitis, cirrhosis, and other liver diseases. AL-T (SGPT) is a liver enzyme that is elevated in liver diseases, and gamma GT (GGT) is a liver enzyme that is often elevated in biliary tract diseases. Alkaline phosphatase is a liver enzyme that is often elevated in liver diseases and bone diseases.

Based on your blood test results, it seems like you might have Gilbert's syndrome or another liver disease. However, it is still too early to make a diagnosis based on the information you provided. I suggest that you consult a hepatologist (a doctor who specializes in liver diseases) for a more detailed evaluation and treatment advice. In addition, the nausea you are experiencing might be a side effect of the jaundice or it might be caused by other reasons such as anxiety or other digestive system issues. If your nausea persists or gets worse, I suggest that you consult a gastroenterologist (a doctor who specializes in digestive system diseases) for further evaluation and treatment advice.

Finally, it is important to note that jaundice can be a serious condition and should not be ignored. Please take this condition seriously and seek medical attention promptly.

634:
The symptoms you are describing could be consistent with a migraine headache, which is a common type of headache that can be characterized by throbbing pain, often on one side of the head. The pain can be severe and may be accompanied by other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

Migraines are thought to be caused by changes in the activity of brain chemicals, such as serotonin, that control the transmission of nerve signals. These changes can trigger the trigeminovascular system, which is a network of nerves and blood vessels in the head that is responsible for our sense of touch and pain.

The pain associated with migraines can often be managed with over-the-counter or prescription medications such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or triptans. If your symptoms are consistent with a migraine, it is important to discuss your symptoms with your doctor to determine the best treatment plan for you.

However, it is also important to rule out other conditions that could be causing your symptoms. For example, neck pain and numbness can also be caused by conditions such as cervical disc herniation, cervical radiculopathy, or other nerve-related conditions. If your symptoms are severe or persistent, it is important to seek medical attention to ensure that any other conditions are ruled out.

It can be effective in treating infections of the skin, such as cysts. However, it is important to use metronidazole under the guidance of a doctor or pharmacist, as it can have side effects and interactions with other medications.

Before using metronidazole, it is important to consult a doctor or pharmacist to ensure that it is appropriate for your condition. They can advise you on the correct dosage and duration of treatment, as well as any potential side effects or interactions with other medications you may be taking.

If the cyst does not improve with metronidazole treatment or if it becomes more severe, it is important to seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor may recommend additional tests or treatment options to ensure that your condition is effectively managed.

650:
Patient: Hi, I went to the dentist last Friday because I wanted to get my teeth checked out. She gave me a filling in two teeth...both the second last molar from the back on the upper left and right side. The filling on the left has given me no trouble since but the one on the right has been painful ever since, not all the time but when I am eating food. I went back to a different dentist on Tuesday (as the other one was a few hours away from where I work) and he filed down the filling for me as it was a little high. However, it is still hurting when I eat...could you advise as to why this is? Could the filling have irritated the nerve or something, or do you think it just needs a while to settle down?

Doctor: Hello, based on your description, the pain you are experiencing after getting a filling may be due to a few reasons. Firstly, it is possible that the filling was placed too high or too tight, which may be causing pressure or irritation to the nerve. The dentist who filed down the filling may have alleviated this pressure, but if the pain persists, it may indicate that there is another problem.

Secondly, if the tooth had a deep cavity or infection near the nerve, the filling may have irritated or compressed the nerve, causing pain. This type of irritation usually subsides over time, but it can take a few days or weeks for the nerve to fully recover.

Lastly, if there is an underlying condition such as an infected wisdom tooth or a cracked tooth that is causing the pain, these conditions would need to be addressed separately from the filling.

Based on your description, it seems like the filling may have irritated the nerve or there may be an underlying condition that needs to be addressed. It is recommended to return to your dentist as soon as possible for a follow-up examination to determine the exact cause of the pain and to receive appropriate treatment. Your dentist may recommend taking anti-inflammatory medication such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to relieve the pain and swelling in the meantime. Please take care of your oral health and maintain good oral hygiene habits to prevent similar problems in the future.

Your wife has undergone a left radical mastectomy and left axillary dissection, and the biopsy confirmed ductal carcinoma of grade 2. Twelve out of 24 lymph nodes were found to have metastatic carcinoma. Despite the PET CT scan showing no critical disease elsewhere in the body and no metastasis, your oncologist has recommended 8 cycles of chemotherapy and radiation therapy to kill any microscopic cells that might not have been detected by the PET CT scan.

Chemotherapy is a common treatment for breast cancer, and it can help reduce the risk of recurrence and prolong survival. However, it also has side effects such as nausea, vomiting, hair loss, and fatigue. It is important to discuss with your oncologist the potential risks and benefits of chemotherapy, and to consider other treatment options such as targeted therapy or hormonal therapy if appropriate.

Radiation therapy can help kill any remaining microscopic cells and reduce the risk of recurrence in the operated area. It can also help relieve symptoms such as pain or swelling in the operated area. The side effects of radiation therapy include skin irritation, fatigue, and a small risk of developing secondary malignancy in the treated area.

It is important to have a thorough discussion with your oncologist about all treatment options and their potential side effects. Your wife's case is unique, and the best treatment plan should be individualized based on her specific condition and her preferences.

**Yes, there is a chance that your son could contract hepatitis C from your mother**. Hepatitis C is a blood-borne virus, and any contact with infected blood, even through a bite, could result in transmission.

However, the risk of transmission is not high. The main way that hepatitis C is transmitted is through direct contact with infected blood, usually through sharing needles or other injection equipment. The amount of blood contact and the condition of the skin at the time of contact also affect the risk of transmission.

If your son did contract hepatitis C, the majority of cases would be asymptomatic. However, he should be tested promptly to determine if he has been infected. If he has been infected, it is important to monitor his condition and receive appropriate treatment if necessary.

In the meantime, it is important to prevent further transmission of the virus. Your mother should receive appropriate treatment for hepatitis C, and any future contact with her blood should be avoided. Additionally, anyone who may have been exposed to the virus should be tested promptly.

No spondylolysis or listhesis is noted, and the bony spinal canal appears normal in diameter. The lower end of the spinal cord and conus medullaris are also normal. The rest of the intervertebral foramina do not reveal any abnormality, and no intraspinal mass or pre/paravertebral collection is seen.

Doctor: Thank you for providing your medical history. Based on your symptoms and test results, it seems like you might have an allergy or an allergic response to seasonal changes. The continuous sneezing, occasional light fever, and blood mixed with your sputum are all consistent with allergies or an allergic response. 685:
Based on your description, it seems like you might be experiencing tendinitis or tendonitis, which is an inflammation of a tendon. The more you use your arm, the less pain you have because your body is producing more lubricating fluid in the tendons, which helps to reduce friction and relieve pain. However, when you walk for a long time or perform other activities that involve repetitive movements, the tendons in your arm may become inflamed and stiffen up, causing pain.

To relieve the pain and stiffness, you can try some self-care measures such as rest, ice, compression, and elevation. You can also try to avoid activities that cause the pain and inflammation to worsen. If the pain persists or gets worse, it is important to consult a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment advice.

In addition, it is important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid activities that may increase the risk of tendinitis. This includes regular exercise, proper nutrition, and sufficient rest. If you have any other health concerns or questions, please feel free to ask me.
686:
Patient: Hi doctor, I had a cold which turned into a cough as usual. I thought that maybe the cough would go away this time on its own but it didn't. Most of the time I have phlegm but sometimes I don't. The last 4 days my right upper chest hurts when I cough. What's the problem?

Doctor: Hello, based on your symptoms, it seems like you might have developed a chest infection. The cough and phlegm are common symptoms of this condition. The pain in your right upper chest could be due to the infection affecting the lungs or the chest wall. I recommend that you get a chest X-ray to rule out any underlying conditions. In the meantime, I can prescribe some antibiotics and cough syrup to relieve your symptoms. Does that sound okay?

Patient: Yes, that sounds good. Should I also take my usual cold medication?

Doctor: You can continue taking your cold medication if you feel comfortable doing so, but make sure to take it at the recommended dosage and frequency. If your symptoms don't improve after a few days, please come back for a follow-up appointment. It's important to monitor your condition closely and seek medical attention promptly if your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns.
688:
As a doctor, I would recommend that you take your son to the hospital for a thorough examination. A&E (Accident and Emergency) department would be the appropriate place to go to get a professional diagnosis and treatment advice.

A concussion is a type of traumatic brain injury that can occur when the brain is shaken or jolted forcefully, which may lead to temporary loss of consciousness or confusion. If your son has any symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, vomiting, headache, or difficulty with concentration or memory, it is important to seek medical attention promptly.

In addition to the lump on his forehead, it is also important to check for any other signs of head injury such as unequal pupils, bleeding from the ears or nose, or a stiff neck. If your son has any of these symptoms, it is crucial to seek medical attention immediately.

The doctors at the hospital will perform a thorough examination and may recommend some tests such as a CT scan or MRI scan to rule out any intracranial bleeding or other brain injuries. They will also provide appropriate treatment advice if necessary.

Please take your son to the hospital as soon as possible to ensure that he receives the appropriate medical attention.
689:
Patient: I was diagnosed with a very low RBC count of 5.8 and an iron level of 2. The doctors in the ER were amazed I was even talking. I had felt ill for many months. I received 4 units of blood. Wow, do I feel better. I'm not bleeding internally, so why did this happen to me?

Doctor: It's good to hear that you're feeling better after receiving blood transfusions. Your RBC count and iron level were very low, which can lead to feelings of illness and fatigue. The doctors in the ER likely transfused blood to help improve your symptoms and overall well-being.

As for why this happened to you, there are several possible reasons. One possibility is that you may have lost a significant amount of blood either through internal bleeding or external bleeding such as a cut or bruise. Another possibility is that your body is not producing enough red blood cells or that your body is not absorbing iron properly, which is essential for red blood cell production.

It's important to investigate the underlying cause of your low RBC count and iron level so that it can be appropriately treated. You may need to see a hematologist for further testing and evaluation to determine the cause of your anemia. In the meantime, it's important to rest, avoid strenuous activities, and eat a balanced diet rich in iron and folate to help your body recover.
690:
As a diabetic patient with early stage Charcot feet, it is important to take the following precautions:

1. Wear special footware: As mentioned, it is crucial to wear special footwear to protect your feet and prevent further damage.
2. Regularly check your feet: Diabetic patients should regularly check their feet for any changes or injuries. Report any unusual changes or pain to your doctor immediately.
3. Maintain good blood sugar control: High blood sugar levels can damage your feet and lead to Charcot feet. Work with your doctor to maintain good blood sugar control.
4. Exercise caution when walking: Avoid walking barefoot or in shoes that do not provide proper support. Use a cane or walker if necessary to distribute weight and reduce pressure on your feet.
5. Seek medical attention promptly: If you experience any pain, redness, warmth, or other changes in your feet, seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor may recommend additional tests or treatment options.

It is recommended to schedule a follow-up appointment with your doctor to discuss your progress and any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
691: Patient: Thank you, Dr. I have chronic back trouble, also had two fusions on my neck I am in chronic pain. Sometimes it makes my right nut hurt, depending on the pain it will go into above my privates and sometimes the pain goes though my penis. I have very little sex drive. I have not had sex with my partner for over 6 months and I have not cum either. I am 52, can you give me some advice?
692:
Patient: My doctor is telling me I should start taking Vemlidy for hepatitis B. The side effects are scary. Should I look for a second opinion? My son wants me to seek a medical cannabis... My brother died of liver cancer 3 years ago after getting a liver transplant. I am worried...

Doctor: I understand your concerns about the side effects of Vemlidy and your brother's history of liver cancer. It is always a good idea to seek a second opinion when making important decisions about your health. You can ask your doctor for a referral to a specialist or another hepatologist who can provide a second opinion.

Regarding medical cannabis, it is a controversial topic and the use of cannabis for medical purposes is still under research. I would recommend discussing the pros and cons of medical cannabis with your doctor or a specialist. They can help you understand the current research and guidelines related to medical cannabis and whether it may be appropriate for your situation.

It is important to stay in communication with your doctor and express your concerns. They can help guide you through the decision-making process and provide support as you navigate your health concerns.
696:
Patient: I have a 7-year-old who has had a few white bumps on his back. They have decided to spread and I am now finding them on his legs, ankles, etc. These bumps are not like pimples, there is no fluid inside that I can tell. They appear to be some kind of rash. Now he is on a few meds for seizure, autism, etc. He has always been one since a little boy that several times a day will ask you to scratch his back. But he says it is not the bumps.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing this information. It is important to know that the appearance of white bumps on the back and their spread to other areas of the body can be caused by various conditions. One possibility is that these bumps are related to the medications he is taking for his seizure and autism. However, we cannot determine this without further examination.

It is also important to consider other possible causes such as allergies, infections, or skin conditions like psoriasis or eczema. To accurately diagnose the cause of these bumps, I would recommend that we schedule a comprehensive examination.

During the examination, we will carefully evaluate the bumps, their appearance, and any other symptoms he may be experiencing. We may also need to conduct some tests such as a skin biopsy to help determine the specific cause of the bumps.

Based on the results of the examination and tests, we can then develop a treatment plan that best suits your child's condition. It is important to address any underlying conditions promptly as they may be affecting his overall health and well-being.

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any further questions or concerns about your child's condition. I am committed to providing you with accurate and comprehensive medical care.
703:
Hello, I am a doctor. I understand that you are experiencing pain and discomfort from a lump under your right nipple. This could be caused by various reasons, including but not limited to breast cancer, inflammation, or a cyst. It is important to get this checked out as soon as possible.

Firstly, I recommend that you see a general practitioner or a breast specialist for an examination and a mammogram (if necessary). This will help to determine the nature of the lump and any possible connection to your nipple warts or wounds.

Secondly, your medication for hypertension may be causing some side effects on your skin, but this is unlikely in your case as the symptoms have only been going on for a week. However, if you are experiencing any other side effects, it is important to notify your doctor immediately.

Finally, I want to emphasize the importance of promptly seeking medical attention for any breast-related concerns. Breast cancer is a serious condition that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment. Please do not delay seeking medical attention for this.

I hope this information helps you. Please take the necessary steps to get this checked out promptly.
705:
Patient: SIR/MADAM, MY GRANDMOTHER UNDERwent ANGIOPLASTY ON 30-08-10 AT GUNTUR (A.P) AND ARRANGED STINT. FROM THAT DATE ONWARDS, WE WENT TO THE DOCTOR ONCE IN A MONTH FOR MEDICAL CHECK-UPS. SHE IS A PATIENT OF HIGH BLOOD SUGAR & BLOOD PRESSURE. MEANWHILE, AT NIGHT TIME, AND FROM TIME TO TIME, HER LEFT HAND WILL CONTRACT. WE REQUEST YOU TO INFORM WHETHER THE STINT IS SET RIGHT OR NOT.

Informative Translation:

The patient's grandmother underwent angioplasty on August 30, 2010 at Guntur, Andhra Pradesh, and had a stint arranged. After that date, the patient went to the doctor once a month for medical check-ups. The patient has high blood sugar and blood pressure. Sometimes at night, the patient's left hand contracts. The patient requests information on whether the stint is correctly placed or not.
707:
As a professional doctor, I understand your concerns and it is important to take your health seriously. However, based on the information you have provided, it seems like your symptoms may be related to your recent illness and the medication you are taking. It is also possible that your symptoms may be caused by anxiety and stress, as bowel problems can be exacerbated by psychological factors.

Here are some things you can do to help relieve your symptoms:

1. Continue to take the medication you have been prescribed. It is important to complete the course of treatment for your ulcer and depression, even if your symptoms seem to improve.

2. Increase your intake of fiber-rich foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, to help regulate your bowel movements.

3. Drink plenty of water to help soften your stool and prevent constipation.

4. Exercise regularly to help improve your digestive health and reduce stress levels.

5. If your symptoms persist or worsen, or if you have any concerns, it is important to schedule a follow-up appointment with your doctor to discuss further testing and treatment options.

In terms of your chances of developing colon cancer, it is important to remember that the risk is relatively low for someone of your age without a family history of the disease. However, if your symptoms persist or worsen, or if you have any concerns, it may be appropriate to consider additional testing such as a colonoscopy. It is important to discuss this with your doctor to determine the best course of action for you.
712:
Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on your description, your son has a horseshoe kidney and had a large kidney stone removed at the age of 2. He has been undergoing regular check-ups and scans at RVH Belfast once a year, which have always come back clear. He is currently 14 years old and has been boxing since the age of 9. However, a recent medical examination by a sports doctor suggested that his horseshoe kidney may affect his boxing career. Your son is very disappointed about this news, and you are not sure what to do.

Firstly, it is important to consult a nephrologist (kidney specialist) to assess your son's condition and provide advice on his boxing career. The nephrologist can review your son's medical history, conduct a physical examination, and order any necessary tests (such as kidney function tests, imaging studies, etc.) to assess the status of his horseshoe kidney.

Secondly, based on the assessment results, the nephrologist can provide specific advice on your son's boxing career. This may include modifications to his training routine, advice on preventing further kidney stones, and regular follow-up care. The nephrologist can also discuss the possibility of treatment options for his horseshoe kidney, if necessary.

Finally, it is important to support your son emotionally during this difficult time. He may be feeling disappointment and anxiety about potentially being unable to box competitively. Encourage him to stay positive, focus on his health, and consult with the nephrologist for further advice.

I hope these suggestions can help you and your son. If you have any other questions or concerns, please feel free to ask me.
713:
Hello! Changing contraceptives is a personal decision, and it is important to discuss it with your doctor to ensure that you make the best choice for your health and lifestyle.

When changing contraceptives, it is generally recommended to wait until the end of your menstrual cycle before starting a new type of contraceptive. This is because each contraceptive has its own unique way of working and side effects, and starting a new type of contraceptive during your menstrual cycle may increase the risk of side effects or other complications.

If you want to change to Cerazette, it is recommended that you wait until the end of your menstrual cycle and start taking it on the first day of your next cycle. This will help to ensure that your body has time to adjust to the new contraceptive and minimize the risk of side effects or other complications.

When changing contraceptives, it is important to remember that each type of contraceptive has its own set of side effects and risks. It is important to discuss these with your doctor and understand the risks and benefits of each type of contraceptive before making a decision.

If you have any other questions or concerns, please feel free to ask me!
717: Please refer to relevant websites for more information, and feel free to ask me any other questions.
720:
Patient: I just started taking prednisone yesterday for a viral infection. No fever. Sore throat and enlarged lymph nodes on the back of my neck. Last night I noticed red spots on my face but I thought I might just be getting an acne breakout. Now they are on my neck, arms, chest and back. They don't really itch and are not very close together. I've taken prednisone before - about 6 months ago I had mono. Am I having an allergic reaction to it or is it probably something else?

Doctor: It is possible that the red spots could be an allergic reaction to the prednisone, but it is also possible that they could be related to the viral infection or another condition. If you have any concerns or if the spots increase in number or if they start to itch, you should contact your doctor immediately. It is important to stop the prednisone if there is a possibility of an allergic reaction. Your doctor may recommend other treatments for your symptoms until they can be evaluated further.
722:
Patient: I think I have a recurrence of CFS (my body is drained after minor exertion), but I am a little worried about a loss of power in my hands. I can't do delicate things, nor can I do things that need strength, such as opening a jar. This has been going on for a fortnight.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your symptoms with me. CFS (Chronic Fatigue Syndrome) is a complex condition that can cause persistent fatigue and a range of other symptoms. Loss of power or weakness in the hands can be a common complaint associated with CFS. However, it is important to rule out any other possible causes.

Firstly, I would recommend a thorough physical examination to assess your hands and any potential underlying conditions. This may include testing your grip strength, sensation, and range of motion.

Secondly, it would be beneficial to conduct some blood tests to rule out any nutritional deficiencies or underlying health conditions that may be contributing to your symptoms.

Finally, it's important to consider the impact of CFS on your overall health. If your symptoms are consistent with CFS, management should focus on symptom control and lifestyle modifications. This may include rest periods, gradual exercise, and cognitive behavioral therapy to help manage the condition.

Please note that this is a general recommendation, and it's important to consult a healthcare professional for a comprehensive evaluation and treatment plan tailored to your specific condition.
727:
Dear Mrs. Barbara Ann John,

Thank you for sharing your health concerns with me. As a doctor, I must advise against the use of urine therapy as it may not be effective and may even pose health risks. Instead, I recommend that you seek proper medical treatment for your shoulder condition.

If your shoulder has been painful and slightly restricted in movement for two months, it is possible that you may have developed frozen shoulder, a condition that can cause stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint. However, only a physical examination and possible imaging studies can confirm the diagnosis.

Fortunately, there are many treatment options available for frozen shoulder, including physical therapy, which can help to restore movement and relieve pain. I encourage you to consult a physical therapist who can provide you with individualized treatment recommendations based on your specific condition.

Please note that frozen shoulder can be a temporary condition, but it can also last for several months or even years if left untreated. It is important to seek prompt medical attention to ensure proper management and prevent further complications.

In addition, it is crucial to maintain good glycemic control with your diabetes to prevent further complications. Please continue taking your medication, monitor your blood glucose levels regularly, and consult your primary care provider for any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.

I hope this information is helpful to you. If you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to ask me. I wish you a speedy recovery from your shoulder condition.
728:
Patient: I am a 22 year old man, I am about 9 stone and about 5ft 4. My testicles have shrunk and gotten wrinkley. I am worried I am infertile as me and my girlfriend have been having unprotected sex for 8 months now and no signs of her being pregnant. I took one course of steroids about 6 months ago, it gave me a form of acne on my chest and back and I have been prescribed tablets from the doctors. I last took one injection of steroids last month. Could this be causing my testicles to shrink and could it be that I am infertile?

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your concerns. It is important to address your questions about your testicles and infertility.

Firstly, the shrinking and wrinkling of your testicles can be caused by a variety of factors. One possible cause is the reduction in testosterone levels that occurs during puberty. However, this should not affect your fertility.

Another possibility is the use of steroids. Steroids can indeed cause testicular shrinkage, but this effect is reversible once the steroids are discontinued. The injections you have received may have contributed to this shrinkage, but it should gradually return to normal after stopping the steroids.

Regarding your fertility concerns, there are several factors that can affect fertility in men. Testosterone levels are one factor, but there are others such as sperm count, sperm motility, and semen quality. If you are concerned about your fertility, it is recommended to consult a fertility specialist for a comprehensive evaluation.

In the meantime, if you and your girlfriend want to continue trying for a pregnancy, it is recommended to continue having unprotected sex during her fertile period. If your concerns persist, it may be beneficial to discuss with your doctor about further testing and evaluation options.

Please note that this response does not constitute medical advice. It is always important to consult a healthcare professional for a comprehensive evaluation and individualized advice based on your specific situation.
729: Patient's son is 8 years old, 4 feet tall, and weighs about 75-80 pounds. He occasionally complains of pain in the middle of his chest, as well as pain in his ankles and headaches. He also has asthma and is currently following an asthma action plan. Sometimes, he says it is difficult to swallow. Can you help me understand these symptoms?
730: Patient: I have extreme fatigue and worsening fatigue upon exertion. I have inflammation and pain in all my joints, nausea, diarrhea regularly Brain fog, memory problems, muscle spasms. Sometimes I lose the use of my hands. I feel dizzy most of the time. Other times, it seems like my eyes are spinning. Sometimes I walk like I'm drunk. Anytime I have to do anything, I have to sleep to make up for it. When walking, I can get pains and my feet and ankles can stop in my tracks.
732:
Hello, I am a professional doctor. Based on the information you provided, there are several points that you should be aware of.

1. CA-125 test: This is a blood test that measures the level of a protein called CA-125 in the blood. Elevated levels of CA-125 can indicate the presence of certain types of cancer, such as ovarian cancer. If your CA-125 levels are slightly elevated, it may indicate the possibility of an underlying condition, such as an ovarian cyst or fibroids. However, a slight elevation does not necessarily indicate cancer. It is important to follow up with your doctor to have further testing and evaluation.
2. Repeat test results: If your CA-125 levels have increased on repeat testing, it raises the suspicion of an underlying condition that may require further investigation. It is important to follow the recommendations of your doctor and have any recommended tests and evaluations promptly.
3. Back pain: Back pain can be a symptom of various conditions, including pregnancy, menstruation, and certain types of cancer. If your back pain is severe or persistent, it is important to inform your doctor promptly.

In summary, it is important to be concerned and follow the recommendations of your doctor. Based on your symptoms and test results, your doctor may recommend further testing and evaluation to rule out any potential conditions. It is important to have a prompt and thorough evaluation to ensure your health and well-being.
733:
Patient: After a gallbladder attack, the urine and cornia turned yellow. I read a response by Dr. Sapan J Pandya on your website that this is expected and should return to normal in a few days. However, some other websites suggest that this could be due to a gallstone passing into the common bile duct. Can this happen and if so, is it a cause for concern?

Doctor: Thank you for the question. It is true that gallstones can pass into the common bile duct, which can cause yellowing of the urine and cornia due to the release of bilirubin into the bloodstream. However, this is a rare occurrence and usually not a cause for concern. If you have been experiencing symptoms of a gallbladder attack, it is recommended to seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor can perform a gallbladder ultrasound to assess the situation and determine if any stones have passed into the common bile duct. If stones are detected, your doctor may recommend conservative management with medication or surgical removal of the gallbladder if necessary.

Please note that this response is based on general medical knowledge and may not apply to your specific situation. It is important to consult your doctor for accurate diagnosis and treatment recommendations.
735:
Patient: Hi, I am a 22-year-old female. I have a very bad cough that doesn't seem to go away. I have been coughing up mucus that seems to be white at times, then watery and clear the next. Sometimes I will cough to the point of throwing up. I have lost sleep due to coughing spells. I had this issue about two years ago and had X-rays done on my lungs and the doctors said everything seemed to be clear, but lately I find it hard to breathe if I try to get a good draw of air, I end up coughing or wheezing.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your symptoms. It seems like you are experiencing some respiratory issues that might be affecting your breathing. Based on your description, it could be an allergy or asthma attack. However, we need to conduct some tests to determine the exact cause of your symptoms. In the meantime, it's important to manage your symptoms to prevent further discomfort and respiratory distress. I will prescribe you an inhaler to help with your wheezing and coughing. You should also consider taking anti-allergy medication if your symptoms suggest an allergy attack. Additionally, please avoid triggers that could worsen your symptoms, such as smoke, dust, and pollen. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek immediate medical attention.
736:
Patient: Hi, I'm 22 years old, 5'9", 170 pounds, and have been very healthy all my life with no problems really. I have a swollen lump right above my upper lip but still touching my lip. It doesn't hurt unless I push on it, but I can feel it there and it's irritating me. The swelling goes down a little if I put ice on it. It's not an open sore just a lump that won't go away. I've had it for about 5 days now.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your symptoms. It seems like you have a swollen lump above your upper lip that doesn't hurt unless you push on it. The swelling goes down a little when you put ice on it, but it won't go away. It's been there for about 5 days now.

Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that this is causing you discomfort. However, it's important to note that this could be a variety of different things, and we need to conduct some tests to determine the cause.

Doctor: In the meantime, it's important to avoid pushing on the lump as this could irritate it further. Additionally, try to avoid touching the area around the lump to prevent any potential infections.

Doctor: I recommend that you continue to monitor the lump and take note of any changes in its appearance or size. If the lump becomes more painful, starts to ooze pus, or if you develop any other symptoms like fever or chills, please seek medical attention immediately.

Doctor: I'll arrange for some tests to be done to determine the cause of the lump. In the meantime, please take care of yourself and don't hesitate to contact me if your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns.
738:
As a professional doctor, I recommend that you go back to the doctor for a follow-up. The duration of your child's cough and the presence of other symptoms, such as silent reflux and fear of throwing up, suggest a need for further evaluation and treatment.

The severe cough that has lasted for over 8 weeks could be due to a variety of reasons, including but not limited to, respiratory infections, allergies, or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is important to conduct a thorough examination and obtain appropriate laboratory or diagnostic tests to determine the cause of the cough and to guide treatment.

If the doctor suspects that the cough is related to silent reflux, it may be necessary to consider additional testing, such as pH monitoring or endoscopy, to confirm the diagnosis and to assess the severity of the condition.

Treatment for silent reflux may include lifestyle changes, such as elevating the head of the bed, and medical management with antacids or other medications. If the cough persists despite treatment, further evaluation by a pediatric pulmonologist or gastroenterologist may be necessary to consider more advanced management options.

It is essential to manage silent reflux promptly and effectively to prevent potential complications and improve your child's quality of life. Therefore, I recommend seeking further evaluation and treatment from a doctor specialized in pediatric gastroenterology or pulmonology.
739:
As a doctor, I cannot provide a final answer about whether you need to take medication for the rest of your life without knowing more about your specific health condition. However, based on the information you provided, your doctor has prescribed losartan tablets for high blood pressure (BP).

Losartan is a blood pressure-lowering medication that is commonly used to control BP. The recommended duration of taking losartan depends on your specific health condition and the advice of your doctor. In some cases, people may need to take blood pressure-lowering medication for the rest of their lives, but this should be evaluated on an individual basis.

Common side effects of losartan include dizziness, hypotension (low blood pressure), and headache. However, these side effects are rare and usually occur only in a small number of people. If you experience any side effects while taking losartan, it is important to contact your doctor promptly.

In addition, it is important to monitor your blood pressure regularly while taking losartan to ensure that the medication is effective and to identify any potential side effects or issues with your health condition. Your doctor may recommend regular follow-up visits and blood pressure checks to ensure your health condition is stable and under control.

If you have any further questions or concerns about your health condition or the use of losartan, it is important to consult with your doctor for individualized advice and guidance.
740:
The origin of Agalactiae Streptoccus is usually through contact with infected secretions, such as respiratory secretions, skin secretions, and so on. It can be transmitted through the air, contact with infected areas, or contact with contaminated objects. Therefore, it is possible that you got infected when swimming in the ocean or swimming pool, or when in contact with other people or objects carrying the bacteria.

The Z pack you mentioned is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that can effectively kill various bacteria, including Streptococcus. It can be used to treat respiratory tract infections, skin infections, and other infections. However, whether the Z pack can clear your navel depends on the type of infection and the location of the infection. If the infection is systemic, the Z pack can help clear the infection; if the infection is local, it may need other treatment methods.

Agalactiae Streptoccus is a kind of bacteria that can be transmitted from person to person, so it is possible to transmit it to your family. Therefore, if you have symptoms of Agalactiae Streptoccus infection, it is recommended to isolate yourself and receive appropriate treatment as soon as possible to avoid infecting others.

Finally, you should avoid swimming in public places when you are sick to avoid getting infected by other people's secretions or being infected by other microorganisms in the water.
741:
Patient: I think I have M.E. as I feel tired most of the time; I stay awake for a long time at night; I have tummy aches and indigestion most of the time. Yet, I eat healthy and have always had a lot of exercise, though now I have little energy, which is very depressing. Doctors can't find anything wrong with me, but life is hardly worth living. There's so much I want to do but can't. Can you help?

Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing such difficulties. It sounds like you may have been diagnosed with Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (M.E.), which is a chronic condition that can cause fatigue, sleep problems, and digestive issues. However, it's important to note that M.E. is a complex condition and can be challenging to diagnose definitively.

Firstly, I recommend that you seek a second opinion from a doctor who specializes in M.E. or chronic fatigue syndrome. They will be able to conduct a comprehensive evaluation and assist in confirming the diagnosis.

Secondly, it's essential to manage your symptoms effectively. Rest is crucial, as is managing your diet and exercise levels. You mentioned that you're eating healthily and exercising, which is good. However, it's important to avoid overdoing it and allow your body sufficient recovery time.

Lastly, it's important to consider the emotional toll this condition can take. Depression and anxiety are common in people with M.E., and seeking support from a therapist or counselor can be beneficial.

Remember, M.E. is a journey, and it may take time to find the right treatment approach that works for you. Please don't hesitate to seek help and support from your healthcare team, as they can provide guidance and assistance along the way.
743:
Patient: I had a discectomy 4 weeks ago. Although my pain is better, it has not completely gone on my right side and I have a new problem on my left side since the surgery. Sudden sharp pain in my left groin and my left foot, the toes suddenly curl up in spasm, very painful! Also, I get a grinding pain in my lower spine after walking a short distance!

Doctor: It sounds like you are experiencing some post-surgical complications. It's important to get these symptoms evaluated by a doctor as soon as possible. The groin pain and toe curling could be related to the surgery, and the lower back pain might be due to vertebral issues or other reasons.

It's essential to follow your doctor's advice and take any prescribed medications as directed. If your symptoms worsen or if you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact your doctor for further evaluation and advice.

Note: The above response assumes that you have already seen a doctor for your post-surgical symptoms. If you haven't, it's important to schedule an appointment with your surgeon or a general practitioner as soon as possible.
744:
Hello, I am a professional doctor. I can answer your son's medical questions.

First of all, I suggest you consult a doctor as soon as possible to obtain a more accurate diagnosis and treatment plan for your son's condition.

In the meantime, here are some general suggestions that may help relieve your son's symptoms:

1. Keep the indoor air humidified. This can help loosen phlegm and relieve congestion.

2. Use a vaporizer or humidifier to add moisture to the air.

3. Keep your son away from any known allergens that may trigger his symptoms.

4. If your son is bottle-fed, try switching to a hypoallergenic formula.

5. If your son is breastfed, consider discussing with your doctor whether you should eliminate any potential allergens from your diet.

6. Use saline drops to clear your son's nasal passages and help him breathe more easily.

7. If your son's symptoms are severe, consider using over-the-counter cough and cold medication, but only under the guidance of a doctor.

8. If your son's symptoms persist despite these measures, seek medical attention promptly. Your doctor may recommend additional testing or prescribe appropriate medication.
745:
Patient: I am a 67 year old post-menopause female who just completed a 10 day regimen of prednisone to treat an allergic reaction I had to a cortisone shot. Within 2 days of stopping the prednisone, I had mild bleeding for about 4 days. My internist tested my urine and blood for a number of infections but did not get any positives. He suggested this may be a gynecological issue. The traces of blood have stopped. Should I be concerned?

Doctor: Based on your description, the mild bleeding that occurred after stopping the prednisone and the tests that did not detect any infections, it seems like this could be a side effect of the prednisone. Prednisone is a corticosteroid that can affect the lining of the vagina, which can lead to mild bleeding or spotting. This is usually temporary and should resolve on its own.

However, since you are post-menopausal, it's important to monitor any changes in your bleeding pattern or any other symptoms that could indicate a gynecological issue. If your bleeding persists or if you experience any other symptoms like discharge, pain, or discomfort, it's important to consult your gynecologist for further evaluation.

Overall, I wouldn't be too concerned at this point since the bleeding has stopped and it seems to be a side effect of the prednisone. However, it's always important to keep an eye out for any changes in your health and seek professional advice if necessary.
747:
Patient: My 4-year-old child was taken to the hospital with severe stomach pain, after ruling out appendicitis and passing some smelly wind. The symptoms subsided and we left. Since then, he has had stomach pain re-occur and now at every meal. He has lost his very good appetite and has lost a lot of weight. His stools are very pale and loose and he has had a few problems with urgency and loss of bowel control. He has a history on his father's side with stomach and bowel cancer. I am wondering if I should have him tested for mesenteric lymphadenitis and if this may be due to a viral infection like hepatitis. His immune system seems to be rather poor, showing not much resistance to infections.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your child's medical history. Based on the symptoms you described, your child may be suffering from a gastrointestinal issue. It is recommended to consult a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and testing. A gastroenterologist can assess your child's symptoms, perform necessary tests, and help determine the underlying cause of his gastrointestinal issues. 

Regarding the possibility of mesenteric lymphadenitis and a viral infection like hepatitis, these conditions can cause similar symptoms. However, it is important to note that mesenteric lymphadenitis is a rare condition in children. It is more common in adults and is often caused by a bacterial infection. In children, it is usually associated with other conditions such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis. 

If the gastroenterologist determines that further testing is necessary, they may recommend blood tests, stool tests, or imaging studies to rule out other potential causes of your child's symptoms. If a viral infection is suspected, your child may be prescribed antiviral medication to treat the infection. 

It is also important to consider your child's diet and lifestyle habits, as they can have an impact on gastrointestinal health. Ensure that your child eats a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, while limiting processed foods, sugary snacks, and fast food. Encourage regular exercise and sufficient sleep to support overall health and well-being. 

Please consult a gastroenterologist as soon as possible to further evaluate your child's condition and determine the best course of treatment.
748:
Patient, I understand your pain and discomfort. It's important to know that herniated discs in the lower back can indeed cause pain that radiates to the hips. Epidural injections are a common treatment option that can provide temporary relief, as you mentioned.

The violent pain you're experiencing on the left side could be due to several reasons. It could be related to the herniated disc, but it could also be caused by other conditions such as sciatica or Piriformis syndrome. Sciatica is a condition where the sciatic nerve is compressed or inflamed, causing severe pain in the lower back and radiating down the legs. Piriformis syndrome is another condition where the Piriformis muscle compresses the sciatic nerve, causing similar symptoms.

In the meantime, it's important to manage your pain effectively. Your current medication is helping to some extent, but it's possible that your pain management doctor may recommend increasing the dosage or changing the type of medication to provide better relief.

Until your appointment next Wednesday, I suggest you take it easy on the left side, avoid any strenuous activities that could worsen the pain, and use heat or cold packs to relieve the discomfort. If the pain becomes unbearable or if you have any concerns, don't hesitate to seek urgent medical attention.

Please take care and I hope you find relief soon.
750:
I'm sorry to hear about your situation. It seems that you have been trying to conceive for three years and have faced some challenges. Based on your description, the endometrium is a bit thin, which may affect your fertility. However, the thickness of the endometrium can vary during the menstrual cycle, so it's not always a clear indicator of fertility.

Pregnancy is not solely determined by the thickness of the endometrium but also relies on other factors such as ovulation, sperm quality, and the health of the fallopian tubes. If your gynaecologist has recommended further testing or treatment, it would be best to follow their advice as they have access to your specific medical history and can provide more individualized recommendations.

In the meantime, it's essential to manage any abdominal or buttock pain, as this can be a symptom of a more serious condition. Please ensure that you seek prompt medical attention if the pain becomes severe or persistent.

If you would like to explore your fertility options further, you may consider seeking a fertility specialist's advice. They can conduct a more comprehensive evaluation and assist you in understanding your fertility options, should you decide to pursue them.

Remember, it's important to take care of your mental health too. Fertility challenges can be emotionally taxing, so please consider seeking support from family, friends, or a mental health professional if you feel it would benefit you.
751: Patient: I fell on Friday afternoon, landed on my elbow, it turned dark green and was swollen and sore. But I could move it fine. It's a little less green today but still swollen and very sore. I can't touch it because of the pain. Should I get it X-rayed or give it a few more days?
753:
I'm sorry to hear about your friend's condition. Based on the information you provided, it seems like her cancer has progressed and is causing a variety of symptoms. The sores in the mouth, difficulty eating, edema in the feet and hands, and diarrhea could be side effects of the chemotherapy or other treatments she has received.

It is important to note that these symptoms do not necessarily indicate that she is at the end of her battle. However, they are significant and require immediate attention from her medical team. It's crucial to ensure that she is being evaluated by a doctor who is experienced in cancer care and can provide her with the best possible treatment options.

At this point, it's important to focus on comfort and quality of life for your friend. If she is experiencing significant symptoms, her medical team may recommend a change in her treatment plan or other supportive measures to manage her symptoms and improve her comfort.

Please discuss these concerns with your friend's medical team and ask for their input on her current condition and treatment options moving forward.
757:
Patient: I have completed 9 months of treatment for tuberculosis pleural effusion. I am experiencing shortness of breath when my nose is blocked. I have consulted an ENT specialist and was diagnosed with nasal allergy only. What could be causing the shortness of breath? My condition gets worse when my nose is blocked. X-ray shows that my lungs are fine, no problem. Please help.

Doctor: After completing the treatment for tuberculosis pleural effusion, you are experiencing shortness of breath when your nose is blocked. The X-ray of your lungs shows no problem, and you have been diagnosed with nasal allergy only.

The shortness of breath could be caused by several reasons. One possibility is that the nasal allergy is causing mild respiratory distress. When the nose is blocked, it may make it more difficult to breathe through the nose, leading to shortness of breath.

Another possibility is that the tuberculosis pleural effusion treatment may have weakened your respiratory system, making it more sensitive to nasal allergies or other respiratory irritants.

It is important to manage your nasal allergy effectively to relieve the shortness of breath. You can take over-the-counter antihistamines and nasal decongestants to relieve the symptoms. If the symptoms persist, you can consult an allergist for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.

In addition, it is essential to maintain good respiratory health. Avoid exposure to allergens and irritants that may trigger nasal allergies. Regularly clean your nasal passages to maintain good respiratory health.

If your shortness of breath worsens or if you have any concerns, please seek immediate medical attention.
759:
Patient: My baby has been passing green stools for the last 20 days. He is a 5 month and 5 day old boy. He has been moving his bowels with every feeding, along with mucus and with a water consistency. We did a stool test and the result was normal. The doctor gave him antibiotics for 5 days, but it didn't cure him. Please help me. What should I do? Should I start giving him ragi porridge as he is losing weight?

Doctor: It is important to note that the color of the baby's stool does not necessarily indicate a problem. However, the presence of mucus in the stool could be a sign of an infection or other bowel condition. It is recommended to continue to monitor the baby's stool and bowel movements, and if the condition persists or worsens, it is recommended to consult a pediatric gastroenterologist for further evaluation and treatment recommendations. Regarding the antibiotics, if they were prescribed by a doctor, it is recommended to complete the course of treatment even if there is no immediate improvement. As for the ragi porridge, it is generally safe for babies to eat, but it should be introduced gradually and cautiously, as it may contain allergens or other components that may not be suitable for the baby's digestive system. It is recommended to consult a pediatrician or dietitian for specific recommendations on introducing solid foods to the baby.
760:
Patient: Dear Sir, my son, age 12 years, has been suffering from fever since April 18th. His temperature reaches 102 degrees Fahrenheit every 10 to 11 hours. The fever is cured with paracetamol tablets. His Widal test results were 1:40 and 1:80. Please suggest a dietary plan as well as treatment. Thank you.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing your son's medical information. Based on the information provided, it seems like your son may have an infection. The Widal test results are also suggestive of enteric fever, but this needs to be confirmed through a blood test.

Dietary Plan: During this illness, it is important to maintain a balanced diet rich in nutrients and fluids. Here is a suggested dietary plan for your son:

1. Start the day with a light breakfast, such as a bowl of cereal or toast with butter.
2. Have a balanced lunch, including a lean protein source (chicken, fish, beans), vegetables, and a small serving of complex carbohydrates (rice, quinoa, or pasta).
3. For dinner, serve a similar meal to lunch, but add some fruits for dessert.
4. Drink plenty of fluids, especially water, to stay hydrated.

Treatment: Until the blood test results come back, your son should continue to take paracetamol tablets to control the fever. If the fever persists or if your son's condition worsens, please contact your doctor promptly for further instructions. It is also important to rest and take care of yourself during this illness.

Please note that this is just a general dietary and treatment plan. Your doctor will provide specific instructions based on your son's condition and test results.
761:
Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis and the struggles you've been facing. Depression, anxiety, and OCD are very common conditions, and there are a variety of treatment options available.

Firstly, it's important to note that your current feelings of alienation and confusion may be a result of your medication. Dosulepin is an antidepressant that can cause a number of side effects, including changes in mood, confusion, and disorientation. If you're experiencing these side effects, it's crucial to discuss them with your doctor immediately.

Your doctor may decide to lower the dosage of your medication or switch you to a different medication altogether. It's also important to note that medication alone is not sufficient for treating depression, anxiety, and OCD. Psychological treatments such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or exposure and response prevention (ERP) can be highly effective in treating these conditions.

In the meantime, it might help to engage in activities that bring you joy and a sense of purpose. This could include anything from hobbies to spending time with loved ones. Additionally, consider seeking support from a support group or mental health professional who can provide you with valuable resources and strategies for managing your condition.

Remember, it's okay to feel this way, and there is hope for recovery. Please don't hesitate to reach out for help.
763:
Patient: My 14-year-old grandson has a lump and some smaller ones in his groin. He has had blood tests that were clear and antibiotics, but the lumps are still there. If the blood tests come back clear, his doctor said they will investigate further. Shouldn't they be investigating now while waiting for the blood results?

Doctor: Thank you for bringing this to my attention. It is important to conduct a thorough investigation to ensure that the lumps in your grandson's groin are not a cause for concern. While waiting for the blood test results, it is appropriate to continue with further investigations such as a physical examination and additional imaging tests such as ultrasound or MRI to better visualize the lumps and assess their nature. These tests may provide more information about the lumps and help guide the next steps in managing the condition. I understand your concern, but it is important to ensure that we gather all the necessary information before proceeding with any treatment or further investigations.
765:
Patient's wife has been in end stage renal failure for almost 2 years now with only 13% kidney function. Patient is the donor for his wife's upcoming transplant. Patient's wife had 5 bypass heart surgery on January 20th. Patient's wife is about to undergo IVIg plasmapheresis to rid her body of an antibody introduced via a transfusion during the surgery. Patient's wife has developed over the last week 4 or 5 bruises, some slightly raised - those slightly raised are painful. The question is, can we assume that these might be due to the progression of the kidney failure rather than another holdup of the transplant?

As the condition of your wife's kidney function has already reached end stage renal failure, the development of bruises may be related to the failure of the kidney to produce enough erythropoietin, which helps regulate the production of red blood cells and prevent bleeding. In addition, the slightly raised and painful bruises may also be caused by the accumulation of fluid due to kidney failure or due to the use of certain drugs.

At this time, it is recommended that you and your wife consult with her transplant team as soon as possible to conduct a comprehensive evaluation and diagnosis. They will consider various factors, including her medical history, physical examination findings, and laboratory test results, to determine the cause of the bruises and develop appropriate treatment plans.
766:
Patient's mother was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (AFib) in May. She is currently taking beta blockers and coumadin. The problem is that she experiences dizziness, particularly in the mornings, which did not occur prior to the AFib diagnosis. She also fell as a result of the dizziness.

The dizziness and falls could be related to several factors. One possibility is that the beta blockers and coumadin may be affecting her blood pressure and heart rate, leading to decreased blood flow to the brain and resulting in dizziness. It is also possible that the drugs are interacting with each other or with other medications she may be taking.

Other potential causes of dizziness include dehydration, low blood sugar, or postural hypotension (a drop in blood pressure when standing up quickly). She may also be experiencing symptoms of AFib that are not related to the medication, such as shortness of breath, chest discomfort, or irregular heartbeat.

It is important to have your mother seen by her doctor as soon as possible to review her symptoms and adjust her medication if necessary. She should also be evaluated for other potential causes of dizziness, such as dehydration or low blood sugar. In addition, she should be advised to avoid activities that could result in falls, such as getting up quickly or walking unsteadily, until her symptoms improve.
767: Hello, your 4-year-old son has been experiencing vomiting and diarrhea for over a month. He does not have a fever. He seems to improve for a few days, but then the symptoms recur for 2 to 5 days. He has already seen a doctor, but they have not been able to determine a cause. He has lost 10 pounds in just a few weeks. Given his age, he is already quite small. I am sorry to hear about your son's condition. It sounds like he has been experiencing significant symptoms for a long period of time. It is important to continue seeking medical attention and to follow the doctor's recommendations closely. If his doctor has not been able to determine a cause, it may be necessary to consider additional tests or specialist consultations. In the meantime, it is important to ensure that your son is drinking enough fluids to avoid dehydration. If he is not eating or drinking enough, he may require intravenous fluids or a feeding tube to support him until he recovers. I understand how worrying this must be for you as a parent. Please continue to work closely with your son's doctor and seek additional advice if necessary.
768:
Patient: Hi, I recently had a Bartholin abscess and it burst last Wednesday. It took about 2-3 days to drain, but the pain is gone now. However, there is severe itching at the moment. Can someone please tell me why this is happening and how long it will take to go away completely?

Doctor: Hello, the Bartholin abscess is a common condition that occurs when there is an infection in the Bartholin gland, which is located at the entrance of the vagina. When the abscess ruptures, it usually relieves the pain, but it can leave behind a raw area that can cause severe itching.

The itching is likely due to the irritation of the surrounding tissues and the discharge from the raw area. It usually takes a few weeks for the area to heal completely, but the itching can last for a longer period of time depending on the severity of the injury and individual differences.

To relieve the itching, you can try to keep the area clean and dry, avoid using harsh soaps or perfumes, and apply a topical cream or ointment that contains anti-itch ingredients such as cortisone or calamine. If the itching is severe, you may need to consult a doctor for further treatment advice.

Remember to keep the area clean and avoid scratching to prevent secondary infections. If your symptoms worsen or last longer than expected, please consult a doctor for professional diagnosis and treatment advice.
770:
Hello, your symptoms could be caused by a variety of reasons. RA (Rheumatoid Arthritis) can affect the joints and other parts of the body, causing pain, stiffness, and swelling. If your ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) was 40, it may suggest an inflammatory process in your body.

The pins and needles feelings, muscle weakness, and blurring vision could be related to RA or other autoimmune conditions. However, these symptoms can also be caused by other conditions such as fibromyalgia, lupus, or multiple sclerosis.

The dizziness and balance issues could be related to inner ear problems, blood pressure issues, or a vestibular condition. It could also be caused by RA affecting the inner ear or the nerves that control balance.
